Seriously the BEST coffee I've had in SF. The staff is really friendly, coffee tastes great. What else would you want?

Super friendly staff! I got the ecstatic iced coffee and it was really good. I got it with oat milk which a lot of places don't usually have. It's a fun and friendly environment to sit and enjoy a coffee. I also got a chocolate croissant and it was so good! Definitely check this place out

I wanted just regular coffee but stumbled in here and was taken in by the very sweet barista.  I mean really...he was awesome.  So sincere and helpful to this, clearly, out of towner.He pointed me to the Mojito which is their specialty.  And it was delicious.  He, in his sincere manner, said if I didn't like it he'd get me something else.  I hate living in a world where nice stands out so damned much.  But it does and it's appreciated.

Philz Coffee on Castro has a beautiful interior! It's so representative of the neighborhood and feels very welcoming. If I lived in San Francisco, this would definitely be a study spot for me. I got a small Green tea which I requested with some honey. It tasted more like Mint tea than Green tea for some reason, but still was good and soothing for my throat.

This place is so so cute! Highly recommend if you're visiting San Francisco. I am a huge coffee lover!! When you walk in, you just smell fresh coffee and it's beautiful. I thought that their order of doing things was really unique, but super cool. You first order from a barista (you just approach one of them and order). Once it's made, they call your name out and you pick it up, taste it for approval so they can change or add something if you don't like it (which was a wild concept to me), and then you take your coffee and you pay for it. The baristas are so nice and helpful, and that was really what made the experience so great.I like medium roast coffee, and Philtered Soul was so incredible that I had to buy a bag to go back home with me. 10/10 great coffee!

I loved this place on my quick trip to SFO!! The barista was so nice - and beautiful with his perfectly set blue eye makeup! I ordered a coffee and sat at a communal table probably for 2-3 hours working. Their outlet set up is amazing for working and they were very welcoming. They also were passing around samples of a new rose coffee if so remember correctly. Not my cup of tea but I loved their creativity!
Good place they make everything fresh. My chai tea was ok, not the best. Coffee is strong and smooth.

First, I love Philz! It's definitely a coffee that I look forward to having but not at this location. I have tried this location a few times and every time I feel disappointed due to wait time and/or not properly made. I am ok with waiting as long as it comes out correctly. I will give it another shot sometime in the future.

copped some sweet sweet, golden, mint mojitos here. i was impressed by peet's out here but philz takes the cake. unbelievable coffee. great caffeine experience, from the clean interior to the bustling and vibrant castro location. my next time in sf i will be back.
Horrible service. Walked in on a weekday and was first in line but stood there for a good 6-7 minutes with no help at all. Bye bitches, I'm off to Starbucks!

Wasted $10 on a bad barista. And we tipped too because we were confident in top quality service from all of our years with Philz. In all our years of tesoras and mint mojitos (no joke, we've had these drinks dozens of times), this is the first Philz to ever make them wrong/poorly. At worst in other branches, they'll just be off by a little according to barista skill and nature. But this was just so off and disgusting. Both drinks were terribly watery. We always order iced. And this one was just mint water or mocha water with clumps of cream at the top. We always have a creamy top. This one was clumped up white bits floating st the top.We very understandingly and kindly brought it up to the barista quietly to avoid having them get in trouble especially in front of the line of customers. The barista had zero apology and blamed the ice. If Philz iced drinks would be watery as hell, I don't think they'd make iced drinks as it would be 10 grades below their standard quality. The barista was more "oh" like we were idiots rather than "oh I'm so sorry I'll do better". The barista made the drinks again and well, they were watery again. It was a nightmare as we tried to down our $10+ wasted dollars through sf.We purposely went to Philz that day instead of Starbucks because we wanted some high quality beverages and to indulge in something beyond basic Starbucks. Spending way over what we'd spend at Starbucks and for something so unbearable is just the worst. We kept saying to ourselves "we shoulda just stuck to basic today".And to reiterate, my friend has been getting mint mojitos and instagramming them all the time for years. We even looked back at the old posts. This mint mojito looked like a disaster--like an earthquake hit sf and the water exploded into a cup and ingredients fell into the cup as well and sat for 5 days and then was served.I've had an iced mocha tesora for years--it is my go-to drink. I know what it tastes like. This version wasn't even a variation or slight shift of quality (which can be expected between branches). It was so beyond off that someone that didn't know how to brew could have attempted it blindfolded and still made it better. Worst Philz experience ever. First time at this branch and first time having a drink poorly made and remade poorly.

Pretty standard Philz spot. Nothing really against Philz coffee it just never has been my thing. I also can't tell if SF has too many people or not enough comfortable sit-down cafes. This place is ALWAYS busy and full of people with laptops grinding away. Definitely plan ahead and come early to grab a seat. Or just awkwardly stand there.. waiting. It helps if you're small and don't take up a lot of space haha.

The coffee was constant with other branches in SF which is comforting, but I kinda getting sick of the attitude from the your majesty at the cashier just about every single times when I visit, and speaking of which, what's with all the families with kids and their huge camera doing in this place right in the heart of Castro the capital of LGBT  neighbourhood? They're here just about everything single time I'm here no matter what time is it!
I love coffee. I love Philz. I have been to several locations all over the state. A few here in the Bay Area LA SD. Every time has been a pleasurable experience. I will be back to this location soon!

We tried their test coffee rosé but I think it was a bit too sweet for our palettes and not enough coffee flavors coming through. As much as I love the area, this coffee joint just doesn't have the friendly and welcoming greeting that I wanted for historically LGBT street. Maybe it's my Midwest mentality that I need to leave at home, but we've experienced better coffee shops in SF but it was an overall mediocre visit.

I can't tell if the baristas are here to make coffee or socialize and groove to 90's RnB.They act so confident as if they heard your order, then ask five times if you wanted almond milk only. Then you have the pleasure of repeating your order one last time to the cashier ... IF you can find one. Thank you, Phil, for making an app to bypass the painful ordering process.

My go to coffee place on the weekends when I want to do work.The coffee is obviously amazing. My favorite drink is the ecstatic ice coffee.There's not too much working space, you need a little luck especially in the afternoon. They have outlets and WiFi.There's indoor and outdoor seating.

I've hammered this place in the past. But for the last three times I've been here all the previous problems have vanished - which is why I came back. I've been greeted and invited to order. Payment was professional. (The product has always been fine). When I recently struggled with a lid, the barista helped me (the first time it happened several years ago the barista-applied lid spilled all over me). Yay. Good job Philz team. A special shout out regarding tea. It's VERY difficult to find straight chamomile tea brewed at coffeehouses and even some tea shops. The chains all have peach or citrus chamomile. Yuck. It's even chancy to get plain high quality black tea. But Philz has both.

I heard about the quality of Philz Coffee before I even stepped foot in San Francisco. I've traveled to this Philz a couple times, being the doe-eyed visitor to the Castro, to study and take in the Castro scene. The space seems to improve each time I visit, with changes to the menu and the interior of the space.I RECOMMEND checking out the menu ahead of time. The coffees vary a lot and have flavors I've rarely experienced with coffee. It can be a little overwhelming looking at the options, and can be a bit annoying if there is a line. I also recommend grabbing a pastry, which looked amazing when I ordered. They even serve Pepple's vegan doughnuts. Definitely going to become my to-go spot when I have a last-minute sweet tooth. OVERALL a frothy four stars for Philz. Love the Castro-focused themes and style of this space- and the coffee ain't bad either!

My husband is a Philz guy and I a Dynamo type of girl-- but this Philz may have changed my mind. Taryn in particular. I came in this afternoon, 11/10/18, and was greeted so kindly by Barista, Taryn. When I walked up to the counter to give my order she patiently helped me find a tea that would suit my needs as I find the coffee to be a bit too strong for my liking. Taryn made me a delicious Iced Chai Tea! Upon leaving she was so kind to ask how I enjoyed the tea to which I was so pleased. my husband, of course, loved his Tesora (regular milk, regular sugar) Thank you to Philz and Taryn for a nice afternoon buzz.
+ Good matcha lattes+ Entertaining, noisy parrot - I didn't realize there was a parrot initially and was very bothered by the random screeching until I realized it was coming from a real parrot

Best coffee in the neighborhood. Hands down. It even edges out Luke's (though barely). They even have good decaf for when I want to drink coffee later in the day. However, the prices for this coffee exceed the neighborhood average by about a buck. (espresso, for example: elsewhere it's $2, here it's $3.25). The bathroom is immaculate. It has zero smell. Service ranges from gruff to super-friendly.The wifi is terrible. Barely useable. I was getting better bandwidth tying my computer to my crappy cellphone. The seating fine. Coffeehouse standard. Not as good as Reverie. Better than Peet's. Four stars!
Love this coffee spot! Lot's of natural light, great coffee and bonus - they have oat milk, yum!

Great location, good vibe, clean space. They buy decent quality coffee and have good cookies. But they use unbleached paper filters and don't rinse them out properly (i.e. at all), so their coffee always has that classic damp paper off flavor.

Friendliest high-quality coffee around.  And that's a high bar.I've spent a lot of time working in a lot of coffee shops in the city, and the guys at Wooden have the rare combination of space, pleasant atmosphere, high-quality espresso drinks, friendly owners, and even some food.It's a great spot to chat with friends or to grab a nice cappuccino before the N arrives.
Jeder made me the best oat milk latte in my life... I'll never be the same. This man is amazing
Best coffee (except for Blue Bottle in Hayes Valley). Love this place.

Don't go here.  The barista was so rude from the moment we walked in I thought he was joking! I went in with my 6 year old who was standing quietly next to me.  I heard a large parrot squawk as I was about to order.  I pointed the animal out to my son. From there an odd exchange ensued, the jist being the bird doesn't like children, don't go close, with a heavy dose of eye rolling and snark.  This is a family neighborhood, not to mention what health codes are you violating???? Needless to say I'm more loyal to Reverie and Pete's than ever.

Put a spring on the door to keep it closed after people walk in and out! Otherwise, great spot with good, pricey coffee. Music is unfortunately always too loud to have a conversation or get much work done.

HORRIBLE !!!Greasy, oil slick coffee. No honey option, "sorry I'm out of it"? Really ... so I give the lady the empty dairy container. You think she'd say anything more than "thanks"? How about refilling it or asking if I needed more which I did. Good-luck here, I'd be surprised if this place can last 2 years. And oh thank you very much, who the fuck is the weirdo with the exotic bird on his shoulder behind the counter? Keep that shit up & you will have a City health inspector up your ass.

Can we first talk about the parrot here? He can make the beeping sound of a city freight truck backing up so perfectly, that I thought someone was getting a delivery to their shop in Cole Valley about every 5 minutes. It's incredible. Besides the parrot, I came here to do some work one day. The place can get crowded and there's very few outlets to charge your devices. But, besides the cute parrot the place is relatively quiet to work in. I had a dirty chai and cheddar biscuit. And that biscuit... whoa. It was carb pastry perfection. I loved it!

My favorite spot for coffee in the neighborhood, and definitely in my top 3 coffeeshops in San Francisco! The staff (Steve and Yvette) are super friendly and helpful, and the drinks are consistently delicious (my go-to is a flat white and they nail it). It's a great spot to catch up with a friend, read, and get some writing done. Come for the coffee, stay to look at the caffeine-themed punny VHS box art in the back.

Matcha latte (w whole milk) was a solid three stars. Good matcha flavor, but not as strong as I like it. Compared to CoffeeShop in the mission and Reveille matcha lattes, Wooden Cafe doesn't compete wellGreat service - they totally made me feel normal despite me asking many questions about the sweetness level. I felt like they were genuinely concerned and really wanted me to enjoy the drinkWould come back if I was in the area, but would not go out of my way for it

Best coffee shop in SF! Despite the heavy competition (there are a lot of coffee shops in Cole Valley) I am so so happy that they opened because their lattes are the best I've ever tasted. Friendly staff, cute African Grey Parrot in the back (Santos), and of course delicious, expertly made lattes.

Best Latte in San Francisco! I come here as much as I can, because of super friendly staff and spacious seating area with great music. Located in a good neighborhood with convenient pubic transportation. Extra credits: great collections of horror movies, and a very cool parrot sometimes will be there~
Staff are jerks. Coffee is fine. For a coffee place in a family oriented neighborhood they really are very unwelcoming.

A hidden gem located in Cole Valley!  I liked this cafe and the drink that I ordered was so good - it felt like a Fall drink.  Highly recommend!  They also had wooden straws (creative). Ordered: the "thing" (iced) $5

A very solid latte. I'd say if you're going to do the Zazie wait, a cup from wooden will go a long way toward making it more pleasant. It's also kitty corner from the muni stop and a good spot to get your pre-commute caffeine.

This coffeehouse is GREAT! They recently added more signage on the outside of the building which I hope will bring in more people because I didn't even realize it was a coffee shop until I finally went inside today. I don't know if this means I wasn't paying attention or if their window signage is a little dark to clearly read from afar/across the street.I love to drink my coffee with Oak milk. I am lactose and I definitely don't like almond milk in my coffee (it completely changes the taste) and soy milk can be a little too thin and watery. Oat milk is so much thicker, so much tastier and it's better for the environment. I ordered a latte with oat milk, there are no real sizes here - the drinks on the board come out as a ~grande size unless you order a cortado (which is inherently smaller). I chatted with the barista the entire time I was in the coffee house - she was lovely and friendly and made a great coffee.The space is well filled with tables and places to stand. I could definitely see myself coming back when I work remotely. It's also right next to a Muni stop so it's very convenient to grab and go on your way to work or your way out for the day.They even have a bird! It was not there when I was here, but there were bird perches set up all over the place.

This is just down the street from our favorite brunch place so we like to grab a coffee while we're waiting in line over there. The decor is nice and cozy with a really unique collection of VHS horror films on the back wall. The coffee is good and the staff is friendly, including an African gray parrot.

$15.00 for two iced lattes that aren't even all that? No thank you. The only reason I didn't walk away from paying that was because the woman had already made it. But I should have. The flavor wasn't all that and it wasn't good. Not sure if the girl just sucked at making the drinks but how do you mess up an iced latte? Just don't go and go to Philz or Tierria Mia
What a charming little coffeehouse with good service. Due to atmosphere, convenience, being open, customer service and that delicious coffee it`s a five star visit.
It's a nice area with 2 hour parking in the neighborhood.. nice and small the coffee shop , tasty  drinks . Better than other place !!

This man knows how to make a latte :) and they have all the milk alternatives, which so greatly appreciate. Baked goods were great! Super tiny spot to grab and go. He has two small cafe tables outside if you want to take a seat. Super close to the Sutter hospital, the only place I found open at 6:30 walking distance to the hospital.
super friendly service. Local owners. Amazing cup of specialty coffee

Best coffee in The City hands down! I live in San Diego (Born and raised in the Bay Area by the way) and this is my go to place when I'm in town. (I used to go to Four Barrel when they were new, but now they suck!) The quality is terrible there so The Coffee Shop is for me. I love The Sherpa, a little rich but excellent! I hope they stay around for years because this is the place to go!

Such a cute little place!! I've had CoffeeShop bookmarked for the longest time, and this past weekend, I got to stop by!!I got an iced latte with oat milk. They have Oatly!! So many places are out right now due to a shortage, but THEY HAD IT!!!!!!! The latte was nice and strong. Bold without being bitter. I thought it was really cute that the ice cubes were made of coffee and not water. The drink tasted even better when they had melted. Such a nice concept!! More often than not, I'm unable to finish my latte before the ice melts, and it just ends up tasting watered down...but not here!!I also got to try the Sherpa (aka Bulletproof). This is made using butter and coconut oil. I enjoy Bulletproof coffee, so I liked this, but the taste may not be for everyone. It's super rich and will leave you feeling fullBottom line: Kinda pricy but pretty much what you can expect for quality coffee in the area. I wanna come back and try the peanut butter honey cinnamon toast!! There was one man running this whole shabang. Genuinely impressed. It's a pretty small place, but there are a few tables outside. Grab an iced latte and make the short trek up the hill to Bernal Heights Park for an SF vibin' morning--hills for breakfast, gorgeous views, and a caffeine buZzZzZzz!!

I'll admit I'm a coffee snob (ha).  But who doesn't love a "hug from the inside?!"  When I heard this spot serves the infamous bullet proof coffee I had to try it and see what all the hype was about.  I've made it at home before but everything tastes better when someone else makes it for you, right? Order their Sherpa coffee (large if you drink as much as I do).  They use Kerigold butter and coconut oil and throw it in a blender with their tasty coffee.  Your first sip of the Sherpa gives you instant energy that'll last through out the day. Parking - street parking
Obsessed. The espresso is clean. The iced americano or cold brew has frozen coffee ice cubes. And they even have organic coconut water.

Great little (read: grab and go) shop with notable iced latte creations. As others have noted, their lattes are made by steaming milk of your choice, espresso, and coffee ice cubes. All of this is a wonderful touch to a nice cup of joe. Minus 1 star as I would rather not pay $6 for a cup.

Lovely coffee shop with lovely owners and employees that always make you feel welcome!  All the coffee here is great, but my favorite go-to is the iced coffee (complete with coffee ice cubes). Food is quite tasty too, especially enjoy the devil inside and amazeballs!

Love this hippy, dippy, trippy coffeeshop. Great coffee, great bites. It's easy to miss, kind of low-profile, and not in a high-traffic area but it's worth a visit!I can also vouch for their Sherpa coffee. Had some today, very tasty and checks the box for Bulletproof coffee. Confirmed that they put butter, coconut, and MCT oil in it...Don't miss out on their oat and other balls. All easy jokes aside, they're filling and seem all natural. They also have a version of egg in a muffin that's great.

This shop really pays attention to the little things - and they matter! A lot! First of all, this is the first place I've been to that actually foams the milk in its iced lattes! A definite plus for me. Also, the ice cubes in my latte were made from coffee so it doesn't get diluted when the cubes melt. The latte itself was quite strong surprisingly (since my lattes usually aren't) and good flavor. Definitely check this cute place out if you're in the Mission District!

Small but mighty!  This place is IT. Coffee-pour over or not(because there are days that I don't have patience for pour over).  Many seriously insanely good gluten free options that are seriously insanely good even if you happen to love gluten. And the savory muffin that is a breakfast in itself?do it. Just do it. Where's the extra stars for super nice baristas?  Can't believe I drive right by for so long.

Love this place. The coffee is so strong and smells amazing. Literally makes me excited how good the coffee smells while I drive. Usually get an iced americano w coffee ice cubes.. mocha is also a go to.

This place is just fine. Nothing special at all. Menu is confusing and crooked. Cold brew honestly tastes like water. Prices are very expensive and food is small. Maybe we ordered the wrong thing but I don't get the hype.

New to the neighborhood and stumbled across CoffeeShop! So thrilled I did. Haven't found oat milk anywhere else in the city yet. Had a fantastic iced latte with the famous coffee cubes and this "devil inside" breakfast muffin/quiche hybrid. What a treat!
Definitely a rockstar coffee shop by Wilson!  Must check it out!  Black Diamond is the bomb!!!

Love, Love, Love Coffee Shop. Best coffee in the city, and I've sampled them all. The space is cozy and the attention to detail from this local owner is always welcoming, tasty and lifts my spirits. I like the Brazil beans (with the well designed label and fun name - J Church) but I try others, too.

great spot to get your day startedI had a few hours before work and needed to get some work done, found this place and I'm glad I did it was very homie, quite and makes great coffeeI had a latte with some delicious chocolate chip cookie (recomendeddddddd) lol
Adorable coffee shop! What a great neighborhood find! The coffee is wonderful and service always very friendly. Total neighborhood gem just off Eureka!

A wonderful local cafe.  Coffee is great, service is friendly, and it is really nice to be a bit off of 24th Street.  I'm always able to get a space to sit and they welcome people working there.  Prices are high, but alas, we live in San Francisco.

The atmosphere is incredibly pleasant, and it's one of the cutest coffee shops I've ever been to. I would highly recommend coming here just for that.The coffee is also very good! Less fruity than most other places in the city (although the almond milk is a little watery)

This charming cafe served up much more than an amazing matcha latte and delectable piece of avocado burrata toast on the morning we visited. Warm and friendly smiles from the two sweetest gentlemen at the counter welcomed us. Packed almost to capacity, I thought for a second about taking my food to-go, but decided to enjoy it here instead. We were lucky to find the last couple of seats in this super cozy spot, and by the time our food was ready a line had formed out the door.The avocado and burrata toast was absolutely delicious! My eyes must have grown to the size of golf balls when I first laid them on it. Fresh is best and fresh it was, the handful of arugula with the creamy burrata on the very thick toast had me savoring every bite.There were so many other great looking and smelling brunch items, coffees and pastries I gazed at as they passed over the counter. Pricey? A bit, but the quality of the what's served isn't lacking. This was my first visit and I've already thought of an excuse to make my way over again!
Truly a place of comfort for the neighborhood. Great place to sit for a cup of coffee, or avocado toast. The staff cares and understands the micro-feel of our neighborhood here.
Came to see an apartment nearby, and stopped here afterwards for some coffee!  Sealed the deal!

I hesitated to write this review because I don't want this place to get over-run but this place is seriously a gem. I also am so surprised that I never knew about this place and I used to live three blocks away--I guess it really flies under the radar! I am a huge fan of Andytown and their Snowy Plover so knowing that I didn't need to drive all the way to the Outer Sunset to get my caffeine fix was an amazing realization.The cafe is located in the residential area in Castro/Noe...you know the part where you have to climb the giant hill to get there and you wonder if your engine will actually make the crest at the top of the hill. What's nice about that is that there isn't as much foot traffic so it has a much quieter, chiller vibe. On a Saturday afternoon, there were actually some available tables--a crazy thought in San Francisco!They offer a variety of coffee options, including the famous Snowy Plover, and also some cool matcha options. The Snowy Plover mixes espresso, sparkling water, brown sugar syrup, and a generous dollop of salted homemade whipped cream. The result is perfectly balanced and refreshing coffee float. It's not overly sweetened like a lot of other coffee drinks so if you're a true coffee lover, don't worry it won't overpower the espresso itself. They also have several food options including Andytown's delicious scones (served with fennel honey whipped butter!) and also some more cafe-like options like avocado toast, etc. It also seems to double as a mini-market as there was a generous refrigerated section and also various goods being sold in a cute bookshelf (random items from Haribo gummy bears to handcrafted pottery--the theme was very unclear to me).My one qualm: wish they opened until 5 or 6 PM...although, they did recently extend their hours to 4 PM daily.

Neighbor's Corner is one of those cafes you always look for but never find. The Fata Morgana of cafes. Only this time it's real. An oasis in a quiet neighborhood - it seems it's always sunny when you walk in to Neighbor. Look outside the clean windows and you'll find palm trees and succulents, neighborhood people walking their dogs and even children (in SF!!). The clientele is great - at any given day you may find a young woman writing her thesis, the Y-Combinator founder working on her pitch for demo day, and a senior citizen finishing that 800 page novel. The staff. Oh the staff. All models of the perfect cafe personel - not too hipster, always friendly and approachable. They even have outlets and good WiFi but don't tell any of the techies. 5 stars whether you are visiting or native. Thank you Neighbor's Corner!

Steven made my day. I'm in town for business the morning before I had gotten some items and suffered a bit of sticker shock at the $15 for three items I got (latte, croissant, and a cold brew) but... it's San Francisco. I've been spoiled with LA prices. The coffee and croissant were Delish. Next day I had found out that my mother was in the ER and was despondent and had to go to my client. I went in for coffee and a croissant again. Steven asked me how I was... and while I love a social contract... I didn't have it in me. "I'm pretty shitty actually...." was my response. He cracked a pun or two about my star-covered dress and he was very sweet. When the latte was done I gave him my card. He pushed it back gently and said "it's on me... I hope things get better."Thank you for seeing someone in pain and helping the little way you could for them. You made me a customer whenever I'm back in SF. For sure. And the coffee and croissant? Totally delicious.

Finally got around to really trying out this local coffee shop and it was incredible. I've been for coffee a few times and it is incredible! They also carry oat milk which I appreciate a lot. I tried their avocado toast this weekend and was definitely impressed. The girl preparing them was meticulous and led to a perfectly portioned out, absolutely delicious toast. I added burrata on mine (11/10 would recommend) and my fiance got the hard-boiled egg on his. Both were fantastic. The side salad was also delicious.Perfect place for a quick brunch and amazing coffee.

Mom and I stopped by for a quick morning pick-me-up, and were pleasantly surprised to find such a cute cafe in the residential area of Castro!  It was also much larger than expected, with a decent amount of seating space (albeit at a communal table) and a bathroom for customers. In addition to the usual espresso drinks and teas, they also have an assortment of matcha specials. Since it was particularly hot the day we visited, mom and I both got iced drinks (even though we have a rule about not drinking anything iced before 12PM). I got the matcha with tonic - which was good until all the ice melted and it turned into soupy green gunk. My mom got the iced chai which she really enjoyed.They have a brunch menu that I didn't fully explore, as well as some packaged meals (including sushi) in their refrigerated display.
If you want to feel like you're coming home, NC is the place.  The nicest people, quietest locale, and great coffee.  Everything to love.
Given the limited food options, I wish I could find out what's available somewhere online. Then I'd make the uphill trek more often.
Exceptional service, really wonderful. The staff is friendly, kind and expecting your needs, always ready to please you. Coffee and toast were delicious and perfectly prepared.

Really cute but overpriced and few options. I came in on a Sunday for breakfast and they were already out of food options by 10am. I got the ham toast and they piled so much ham on top it was hard to eat (needed a sharper knife). Overly fancy in my opinion.

Excellent cafe. Friendly staff, great coffee, not too busy, tucked away in a beautiful part of the city. They use AndyTown beans here. Great almond milk lattes. The baked goods are also fantastic. There's a small food menu but everything on it is delicious. This is one of the best cafes in the city in my opinion.

Neighbor's Corner is the corner coffee shop that we all wish we had. I went there for breakfast several times recently and enjoyed a variety of beverages. Like Andytown, they have both the snowy plover and matcha plover, which are well-executed. The drip coffee comes with free refills, a pleasant surprise to a non-morning person. I tried the avocado toast, which comes with a huge slice of bread, as well as some deliciously spicy avocado. The egg was hardboiled, which is unusual but not bad. The scones with the seasoned butter are fantastic and definitely worth trying. To be honest, I was sad that I didn't have time to try all of the baked goods because they all looked amazing.There's also a refrigerator with various prepared food from recognisable SF restaurants, as well as some jams, coffee beans, etc. for sale.The service here deserves a special callout. They are the friendliest group of people that you could possibly find. They know all of the people who come in, as well as their associated pets. It really defines what a local coffee shop should be.
I had the cafe au lait and savory scone. Both were excellent. Lovely local establishment. Tad pricey but delicious.

Love everything about this place! Very clean and modern aesthetic all around. Ample tables space and seating. Cozy and chill vibes. Warm and friendly staff (Steven is a sweetheart!) The macarons are incredible and the matcha latte is divine. Hopefully they can introduce more breakfast/brunch options soon! Looking forward to visiting this space more!

A standout corner coffee and bakery shop nestled in Noe Valley. I spent the weekend visiting the bff and we walked with her dog to this gem of a place. The Matcha Latte was perfect and the Currant Scone w/ fennel butter was so satisfying on that cold day. The lady who helped us was lovely and sweet. She even went outside to give water and give hugs and pets to our dog. The shop is a modern meets industrial design. Bathroom was clean and had cool decor. This shop also carries bottled drinks like kombucha, ice cream, and healthy food/snacks. Perfect place to catch up with friends over a nice cup of joe, do some work (I did see a girl with a whole laptop on a stand setup), or relax with a good book.

Very nice quaint coffee shop with friendly baristas. Good prices for the drinks too. I had the honey hazelnut latte and it was great. The milk was steamed to perfection and the foam was so nice and light. They have many tables and free WiFi. Dog friendly as well!
Headed here for the afternoon to work -- found a spot easily, while enjoying a great cappuccino.
If you truly like good coffee this is the place to go in the neighborhood. Definitely avoid the overly sweet beverages from the Starbucks across the street!

I want to love Bernie's as much as everyone in this neighborhood but I feel like it's a hit or miss with their Hazelnut Latte. I feel like everyone who works here makes it different and some make it great. I don't know but I feel like every time I try this either iced or hot, it's made differently every time.I love how many older gentleman sit outside on a sunny day to enjoy their coffee and how it's filled with a more older crowd than the Starbucks younger crowd. It makes me wonder why they enjoy this place so much and what they order. I also don't like how they charge so much for an alternative milk and how the hazelnut price went up as well. When I first tried it, it was in the $5 dollar range but it is in the $6-$7 dollar range with subbing the milk. That's my only compliant. I haven't tried any other drink from them but there is a lot of hype for this hazelnut latte. Sometimes the people on the bar are nice and sometimes they seem rude.

This is a true community-focused cafe. You're treated as an individual, with an abundance of kindness, not as a bother or with attitude that so many "hip" cafes often serve. One morning, on a trip to Bernie's with my crazy toddler, I ordered a croissant and latte before realizing that I the morning scramble I had forgotten my wallet at home. Bernie insisted on making my latte and giving me the croissant, saying, "This is my cafe. You have to have breakfast. Pay me back later." There's no way the nearby Starbucks or La Boulangerie, who Bernie's competes with, would have had the same response!  I went back as soon as possible to pay her back, and I now go out of my way to stop there, because it's so important to support a local business with such heart and generosity.

Favorite coffee shop. Ever! A place that just feels like home. Super kind baristas, the owner is as sweet and friendly as they come, and the drinks are top notch. My first choice when it comes to a cafe to spend my "work from home" days. Thank you so much, Bernie. This place is a gem!
Very mediocre coffee. You pay $5 for a latte, you expect a trained barrista and excellent beans. Go to Sight glass instead. In fact, the owner should go there and take notes.

I had a terrible cappuccino from here the other week. It was in a to go cup and I'm not kidding you when I picked up the cup it felt like there was nothing in it. It was mainly just foam in the entire cup and when you got to the coffee it was watered down and bitter. The customer service was nice but they must have just really screwed up my cappuccino. Maybe just get something else if you come here.

Neighborhood-coffee lovely place. Welcoming and friendly staff, really good coffee (loved my americano) and delicious desserts. Love the vibes here. Nice place to drop by on your way to get your coffee-to-go.

This space is the place!  The staff work together like a family, and we are guests in their home.  It attracts a good set of vibes, between patrons chatting and studying.  The owner steers this ship with a smile and a heart of gold!

The ambience is great and the service is fine. It's a great place to study. However my cappuccino was all foam. Seemed like the barista tried to fill the to-go cup with foam on top of the espresso shot...a true cappuccino is better proportioned than that and won't fill a typical to-go cup. Also, they have for-here dishware and didn't ask us if we'd be staying.
Great service and great pastries. However, the coffee was terrible.  My cappuccino was all foam and my latte was all milk.

Such a lovely place--friendly staff, delicious pastry, and relaxed ambience. Maddeningly, I realized I forgot my wallet as soon as I walked in the door. The barista (owner?) told me I could pay my tab next time. It was such a friendly gesture, especially since I'd never stopped in before. (FYI, they also accept Apple Pay.) She seemed equally nice to everyone else who walked through the door--I definitely got the "small town coffee shop" vibe, where everyone knew and liked each other. I had a small spinach quiche, which was pretty yummy. And the staff were pretty cool about letting me chill at one of the worktables for an hour. They even have a free phone charging station and WiFi. If I lived closer, I would definitely make this my go-to spot.
Great coffee and staff. An actual small business, owned by a San Francisco native and neighborhood local--a rare treasure in this day and age.

Super homey cafe with a wonderfully welcoming staff, and dope soy lattes. As a student, I appreciate the ability to camp out here in a sunny window and study away with some fun music in the background. Definitely one of my new go-tos in the city
I love this place, so quaint and peaceful. If you want a perfect mocha and a relaxing atmosphere then go to Bernie's!
Love the local vibe!  Fast internet and power outlets!  Coffee and pastries are excellent also.

Bernie's is my favorite coffee shop in the city. I love the vibe. Bernie and her staff are wonderful people and they make the best coffee. Highly recommend the honey hazelnut latte or iced Bernie. Stroll right by the Starbucks down the street and visit this neighborhood gem. You'll be glad you did. :)

I would be lost without this place. Bernie's is the perfect neighborhood coffee place - not just great coffee and great atmosphere, it's about the people who work here and how welcoming they are, and how they get to know you and you get to know them. The whole crew is amazing, led by Bernie who is a delight and can put anyone (even a cranky 2 year old or a shy 5 year old) in a good mood. It makes the neighborhood truly feel like a small town and you can't put a price on that. I love it, my kids love it, the whole family loves it. Thank you Bernie!!

Bernie's is the local coffee shop every neighborhood needs or it should be so lucky to have. You witness the love when Bernie is working as she greets and has personal conversation with the regulars and quick to welcome new comers. Having move to SF from Philly it was such a great to find this gem. They can also make a delicious cup of coffee and once they become familiar with your order you don't have to wait.

The coffee is delicious.There is seating area inside where people study and talk. I'm not sure if they have wi-fi. There's also seating outside, which means that there's space to sit with your dog.Did I mention the coffee is delicious? I feel like that's the main thing to know about a coffee shop.
3.5 if I could ...Cons No WiFi. Coffee is alright, not the best. $5+ pastries. ProsOpen spaceLots of seatsClean

Upscale, fresh coffee spot in the heart of the Valencia Street design district. This is a great place to bring your computer and books and live the life of a digital nomad. Bright and airy location, with an open and spacious feel. There's a front area and a back area divided by a little countertop with seating. The back area has a long communal table, flanked by three smaller tables, each with two chairs. The front area has more light, but the back area is where the people really get down to business. A small but beautiful outdoor green space, is located in the back, for looking out and bringing in fresh air.Summary: Nicely lit, spacious architecture with positive vibes.

Nice place. Staff was very helpful on selection of coffee when I couldn't make up my mind. Ended up with an Americano which was made quickly and correctly. Thanks for Yelp for locating this for me, otherwise I would have missed it.

Amazing ambiance and vibe. Very hip. Staff is super friendly and they have very good lattes. The shop is very simple and well decorated.FYI, this coffee shop is more like a place to chill rather than get your work done since their seating are all outside.

Fantastic coffee, fantastic employees, great seating. I used to love this place but the last couple months they've been playing the absolute worst music ever. Slow 1970s era love ballads--horrible. It has severely negative mood-altering affects on me and has completely ruined the atmosphere.

They have oat milk! I live nearby and this is my favorite spot to get an oat milk latte. They have great pastries as well - an assortment of croissants, scones, and vegan donuts. It's probably not the best spot if you're looking to get work done as it gets pretty loud, especially on the weekends. The line can also get very long on the weekends, sometimes almost out the door. But the coffee is great!

Came here with a couple of friends on a Sunday evening. Found parking easily on the street. The place has good ambience inside, decent seating and clean restroom. Husband got a cappuccino but it was served lukewarm. When we asked the barista to make it hot, he said cappuccino is supposed to be served warm, which I didn't think was right. Anyway he got us a new one which was better than before but still not hot. I didn't want to ask a second time so left it as is.

Well, the coffee was decent. But I don't know if any coffee shop qualifies as a coffee shop without wifi. Or power source. I walked in to get some work after looking at people who had their laptops propped up, and was disappointed.

Visited last Sunday while I was checking out Mission district for the first time (it's semi-crazy how it is my first) but wanted to visit this place since I drink coffee like water. Disclaimer: I cannot really take strong coffee - even for americano, I always order as single shot or ask to put extra extra water to the drink so that it is more water downed and diluted. It is simply because of taste that I cannot take rather than caffeine.I ordered cold brew recommended by a staff and as a person who does not drink cold brew normally as I wrote above for my liking for coffee- I gotta say I really enjoyed it. It did not have sour taste which I commonly find in cold brew from starbucks and anywhere else but the ambience was hip and cute. Would definitely comeback when my second visit to Mission happens ;)
Had a great cappuccino here on my first stop of delicious coffee spots in SF. Cute space with friendly staff. The line was out the front door but moved quickly.

This place is very cute spacious and comfy.  Plenty of seating with two individual bathroom stalls.  Back of the cafe has a large window with tropical plants making it appear a bit less city-busy.  Coffee of course is great and their tea is delightfully served in a clay pot on a wooden tray. There's of course pastries, mostly if the sweet kinds, but a vegan sausage croissant roll as well. I was tempted, but I didn't dig in. For the healthier eaters, there's housemade granola with Chobani Greek yogurt.  Outlets along one of the walls for those laptop users but expect to tether your own.  Don't forget the coffee card, buy 10 get 1 free, Apple Pay and great service.

Very hip. Not sure if it's a good thing though. Atmosphere was weird. Coffee was ok. Cutlery/milk/lid station was really dirty, sticky and messy. The staff looked annoyed. The restroom could be cleaner. I loved the art on the walls.

Nice ambiance and amount of seating. The light colored wood, high ceilings, and clean decor makes it trendy and calm. The place was kind of noisy, mostly because it's echoey, so if you're looking for a quiet place to work it may not be the place for you. It's a nice place for socializing and grabbing coffee with friends. My main complaint is the price. I got the Dandelion Mocha which was $6.25. It was a good mocha and I appreciate the local touch but I did feel a little guilty spending $6.25 on a drink, but I guess that's the cost of coffee in SF.

This is one of the two places that started the 3rd Generation coffee revolution in San Francisco (the other is Blue Bottle).  I still like their coffee as much as i did 15 years ago, but with the modernized glam renovation, the spirit of the place went away with the old Roasting machine in the back. When I visited last week, I found the cashier robotic and the barista didn't bother to call my name (on the order ticket); she just put the coffee on the counter, turned to her co-worker and chit chatted.  The place wasn't even crowded.So, great coffee, but indifferent staff.   I miss the old place......

nice place for coffee in mission district as it's a big open space with a modern and clean atmosphere. the light fixtures are unique and a cool touch to the place. i wish they had flavors for coffee like a vanilla latte for example, but the coffee was still good nonetheless. I've definitely had better, but I still enjoyed it. Service was ok.

What I had: Iced chai with almond milkVisit date: February 18, 2019First time? Yes.This place gets crowded! On my visit there was a line - it goes by fairly quickly and my drink wait time was about 10 minutes. It was a Monday holiday so not sure if this is the normal scene. There's lots of seating, but again, there were lots of people, so it's one of those 'jump on the table as soon as people get up' situations.I had an iced chai 'for here.' They serve the for here orders in glass/ceramic ware. My drink was nice and creamy, just a touch sweet. It was perfectly refreshing. The atmosphere is on the louder side, but there were also a number of people doing work on laptops - the lighting is nice for it.
I like their lattes. I have to hold back because I can easily drinking 2 or 3 they are so smooth

Big shout out to Ritual's single origin espresso beans, Sweet Tooth Esperanca: Chocolate Topazio, Brasil. Maddeningly, exquisitely and incredibly delicious!!! The Ritual growers and  roasters have outdone themselves with these beans.
Cashier was a dick- not coming back.Nuff saidThe place is pretentious as well with stops of rubber hung up. It looks like garbage. In fact, I think it actually is garbage!
My favorite coffee shop to work. The coffee is on point. There is great seating with an option for a patio. I wish they had stronger food options. Sometimes I need a heavy snack like a bagel.
Nice place.  Limited menu.  Offering a $3.75 donut.  Very SF.

Low-key would be an overstatement for this easy-to-miss coffee stop on West Portal. I barely noticed it when I strolled by as I saw a particularly animated laptopper conducting a particularly challenging meeting on his headphones. It didn't seem to bother the young barista who was focused on the video playing on her smartphone. I didn't blame her. Except for a work meeting happening in the back, it was as still as a tomb and took my passive-aggressive throat clearing to get her attention. From there, it was smooth sailing as I ordered an unchallenging $4 Au Lait (photo: bit.ly/2JiJ0nN). It was enough and off I went.COFFEE - 3 stars...a decent albeit sweet au lait from their own beansAMBIANCE - 3 stars...certainly quiet on this block of West PortalSERVICE - 3 stars...ah, youthTOTAL - 3 stars...if you happen to be in the 'hoodRELATED - Off to the Sunset? Here's a collection of places I've visited and reviewed: bit.ly/2EI8eIJ
Coffee: perfectSpace: good for working and the outdoor area is lovely Staff: super friendly Highly recommend

This coffee shop is very bright & had a welcoming vibe. Like another helper has said, I don't think this is a $ establishment. The prices are pretty high, but maybe it's because we're in the city. When we went, they only had the barako beans, which is a very dark and bitter roast. I'm glad I got a matcha latte because I'm a medium roast kinda gal. On to the matcha latte... it was honestly lacking the matcha flavor I was wanting based on other great reviews. Maybe it was just my cup, but was latte was quite watery and I had no honey flavor until I got to the very bottom of my cup. The lattes itself were made beautifully, the milk frothed perfectly, but the flavors just did not wow me.

New-ish place. We were sad to see Green House go but Ballast has been an awesome addition to the neighborhood, great for the days when Peet's is feeling too generic. Enjoying a wonderfully strong latte this morning, really taking the edge off the Monday fog.

Ok the lack of art problem is solved, now they hang art from local artist and students on their walls. They have slowly been adding plants and arts and it looks great! I have to say, the dollar sign is not correct for a coffee shop, I would say $4.5 late would be a two dollar sign category. Regardless, they have good coffee, nice decor inside, and my favorite is their backyard. I just go there to have some coffee and sit in the sun. :)

Matcha latte was great - strong and flavorful like it should be. Definitely one of the best matcha lattes I've had in the city. The vibe is relaxed and inviting, and it's easy to get work done. Modern but not overly gentrified, cozy but well kept. Extra points for the r&b jams. SF native approved!

Not bad at all! Came here on a Saturday afternoon looking for some coffee and a place to work. I've visited the old coffee shop that was here before it became Ballast and the space has definitely brightened up. I ordered a cappuccino and sat at one of their smaller tables to work. It seemed like a popular place since everyone around me was there working on their laptops, homework, or writing, which created a great working environment for me. They apparently have outdoor tables which I would love to check out once the weather gets nicer. Their single working tables are pretty small, and the bar-like counter was also small. There is also a larger table in the back of the shop if you're looking for more space.

Visited this coffee to shop after my workout at the local barre studio. Barista was friendly, the place wasn't too busy and my latte was delicious. The environment was perfect for some reading and relaxation after my midday workout. Will come again!

YuckThe former Green House Cafe was warm and inviting. It had cozy areas for either solo work or small groups.  It had FOOD and it was pretty good.  Now.  It's cold, modern, horrible tinky music that's way too loud and distracting.  The new modern look and layout makes all sound reverberate and bounce off walls.  It's about as warm and inviting as a refrigerator.Now.  No food!  And their wall board that lists beverages is impossible to read unless you walk behind the counter and get on top of it!They were also out of the coffee they claim to specialize in.  Strange place.  Won't be back

I love visiting new coffee shops in the city but I was a bit disappointed by Ballast. Reasons include: they were out of their speciality barako blend (special coffee blend from the Philippines that I was excited to try) and the matcha americano I got was so bitter and tasteless that I couldn't finish more than half of it. I also love matcha too so it was surprising that I didn't like it at all.I did like the minimalist decor and there were a lot customers there with their laptops enjoying their day. I also enjoyed the Third Culture mochi donuts. I tried the ube and passion fruit. I will have to think about if I want to go back and try their special blend.
This place is very chill and clean. Plays good selection of music and staff are quick to act.

This is a really great coffee shop. It feels like home and there is plenty of seating, tables, and even an outdoor courtyard that is really nice. Their coffee means I tried that day was from the Philippines which was really different. The staff was friendly and I really enjoyed my time there. Plenty of plugs and Wi-Fi too which is good if you have to do some work on your laptop.I'll be back to Ballast Coffee.
Good coffee and quiet place.  Lots of people in raining days. It's a little hard to find seats on a busy day. But for the coffee, I would recommend for sure.

Ballast Coffee is a nice work space. Came in around 12:30pm on a Sunday afternoon and it was pretty packed, there was no more indoor seating but there was space on the patio outdoors which was super nice, but unfortunately there are no outlets. By 2:00pm the place was packed, including the patio so if you're interested in studying or working here probably aim to get here earlier in the morning.I got the Just Like Honey tea, which was $4. It comes in a nice glass teapot that turns into a cup lmao which I thought was super cute. The tea itself was okay; would have liked a little bit stronger flavor personally but I still enjoyed it.I left about 1.5 hours after getting here because my laptop died lol. So yeah, if you're trying to do a work day here, probably try to get here earlier. Would recommend around 9am-10am.
Definitely NOT OPEN today, Christmas Eve. Ignore Yelp's claim of special holiday hours. You'll have to get your cappuccino elsewhere today.

Tried this place randomly when me and my bf were looking for a place to grab a warm tea and coffee. The outside is pretty nondescript so I  probably wouldn't of noticed it if I wasn't looking for it. We came about a half hour before closing and got a matcha latte and cold brew. Both were pretty good, though I added a little of sugar to my latte since it wasn't sweetened like most places. The service was nice and the atmosphere was pretty chill, mostly small tables with people on their laptops. I also thought it was funny they played the closing time song when they were closing, which is a nice way to tell people to leave :D

I've been an irregular customer, as it were, since a couple of months after Ballast opened. I was not a habituee of the old joint that seems to have been beloved by many.  Even though I dig the space, I'd file this cafe under 'Hit or Miss'. I've had well-rendered drinks from (one of the) owner(s) who is there on and off. More often than not, I've had drinks made by folk who aren't actually up to snuff yet in the drinks-making department. This means, of course, that one is either spending four plus bucks on a good milk and espresso drink or not. And the latter scenario bunk. I mean, who likes paying to be a guinea pig? New hires learning how to make drinks on the job, i.e. drinks patrons are shelling out bucks for ain't kosher. (I understand that this is a somewhat common practice, but I still don't dig it.)The last time I was in Ballast, a new hire (the boss was training him while I was there, so I'm not guessing that he was newly employed) was making my capp while making small talk with the owner. I had wanted the boss to make the drink, but no such luck. I was hoping the new-hire wouldn't be distracted by the chat, but, given that the milk was overly hot and the espresso had a talc/tannic quality about it, it would seem that he had been. Dude set the drink on the saucer, gave not one glance at me, and, while still facing his boss, told him that he was unhappy with the foam art on my drink. I'm one foot over the counter from you, so why don't you not talk about how your drink doesn't measure up in front of patrons, or tell me directly. In all reality, I don't give a fig if you can make a feather or a heart or a gosh darn toy poodle in the foam. I do care that you don't scald the milk, do have the right grind, do have a machine that's been correctly calibrated, etc. It's substance over form all day long. If you can achieve both, then fab. If not then err on the side of the drink being balanced.  If you don't really care how your drink tastes or if you're not ordering espresso and milk drinks, then Ballast is a modern, tidy space you may well enjoy spending time in.**Back patio seating. **Tidy loo.

I was browsing for new coffee shops in the city when I stumbled upon Ballast Coffee here on yelp. I did a quick glance on their page and saw the word "Barako" in bolded letters on their highlighted reviews. I thought "No waaaay!" so I clicked on their website and confirmed that they do serve Barako coffee - it is nice to know of a coffee shop who proudly serve coffee from my home country :)I tried their coffee as soon as I can which was the 10 minutes it took for us to drive to the coffee shop and I am happy to share that it is now one of my favorite coffee shops. Parking around the area is not hard to find, they have cute seating in their backyard and the baristas are nice.

I had the New Orleans iced coffee and was not disappointed. Usually I pour a handful of sweetener and lots of cream, however the coffee was just light and sweet enough without my extra additives. The price is comparable to any other boutique coffee cafe. Service was fast and friendly
I am here by naming this my official last stop before leaving the city anytime I come to San Francisco. Public bathroom plus bluebottle coffee equals win win win. I love you

I am addicted to Blue Bottle Coffee.Simply wonderful, my top selections include the Hayes Valley Espresso, Night Light Decaf, and many of the single origin roasts. When in San Francisco I tend to frequent the Mint Street Shop, great vibe, wonderful service and just a nice way to start and tackle the day.

I had high expectations given the reviews on Yelp, and despite that I agree with several reviewers sentiment this is probably my favorite coffee. The avocado toast was delicious, nothing special but it hit the spot. Located in a corner of Mint Plaza, The vibe is of an urban coffee shop, but the seating is limited. There are a few tables outside though which is nice. The service is friendly. During busy times, the lines can be long and the waiting area can get crowded too.
Went here for the 2nd time a few weeks ago, around 9 am. There was a line, just like before. The food was delicious, the coffee was good too.

Blue Bottle Coffee itself I'd give 4 stars, but this specific location has its faults.There's a certain price I'm willing to pay for my daily cup of joe. $4.50 for a latte is comfortable. $5 is "I'm not coming here everyday" territory. Slap on that "Healthy SF Surcharge" and that $5 is now $5.20. Ok fine, 20 cents; I've already decided I'm not coming here every day but I'm fine contributing to these nice employees' healthcare costs. HOWEVER, ONLY THIS LOCATION ALSO CHARGES SF SALES TAX. So now that $5 latte is $5.62 and this officially became "I'm only coming here because I'm desperate and it's the nearest coffee shop and/or everywhere else is already closed."There is no fucking way I'm paying $5.62 for a latte every day, especially when there are so many other great options available in this neighborhood. SF is spoiled when it comes to excellent, locally roasted coffee, but this particular section of SoMa is as dense as it gets for top notch coffee options. Sightglass Coffee, Four Barrel at Pentacle Coffee, and Saint Frank are all within a few blocks radius for my daily, within-my-comfort zone fix. East SoMa may have all the new high rises, but you best believe West SoMa is coffee mecca.If you're not coming here every day and just want to check out the location, there a few cool perks (I know, complete mood switch lol):-17ft Ceiling Espresso - Most Blue Bottle locations serve their Hayes Valley Espresso by default. This location serves a special blend named after the specs of this Mint Plaza building. It's a subtle, delicious change especially if you drink Blue Bottle so often that you're almost toooo accustomed to the taste-Siphon Bar - At $8/$14, this is definitely not a daily cup of coffee thing lol. But if you're a coffee aficionado and appreciate the unique methods you can extract a lovely brew then this is something you definitely gotta try. Once(?) they had an extra special single origin coffee from Yemen for $20 so if you're really a bean seeker keep your eyes peeled. Only available between 8AM-2PM.-Nel drip - Blue Bottle has their own custom dripper that they use for most pour-overs, but they also do Nel drips for $10. This cool contraption produces an interesting, more viscous brew. Only 3oz so treat yo self.All things considered, I still come here but not as often  as I could because I drink way too much coffee and have to budget or else I'd be living wrecklessly. The staff is extra friendly, the location is set in a historic plaza, and coffee lovers can swoon over the offerings here.

Great coffee; smooth lattes.Avocado toast is okay. Idk what the hype is about. Always a line so it takes about 15 minutes to get your coffee.They just changed to paper straws idk why.... I thought their blue straw was a signature mark that I loved having bc it was so unique!!!!!!!!
Yummy new orleans coffee. Came as expected. Good treat.

This location is a little tucked away from the busy bustle of Powell and Market. I usually meet people around Powell when I get off BART, so when I'm early, I like to pop in here to grab a cup of coffee while I wait for my friends. Most recently I had their cappuccino with oat milk (offered, but not shown on the menu), and it was perfection. Staff are always so friendly here!

This was a cute little coffee shop that has great drip coffee. I ordered the Brazil coffee and it was nice and strong. There was a line out the door when we arrived and I had to wait 5-10 minutes after I ordered to get my coffee.

I love trying new coffee places so we had to stop by when we were in the area. Look for the blue bottle since the name isn't outside and could be easily passed up. The line went pretty quick and the cashier was nice. I ordered the mocha and it was pretty sweet but good. Strong coffee but not over whelming. Not really any food options besides pastries. They have a bathroom that you need a code for so ask an employee if you need it.

Pretty bougie place but the hype isn't letting me down. I only ever came here twice and I had the same order, an iced mocha but the second time around I tried it with almond milk and I actually quite prefer it. Although it's an extra dollar, it was worth it because my lactose intolerant a$$ would have never forgiven me if I had gotten the courage to ingest actual f**king dairy. I also had a couple pastries and they were definitely tasty. One was the blonde mini corn bread (I think that's what it was ‍) and the rose flavored pastry. Very aromatic but wasn't entirely my cup of paste-tea-ree (har har). Would totally come here again.pretty low-key location too and it's next to a couple dispensaries if that's anything worth adding lol
The siphon coffee here is absolutely delicious. Same for avocado toast.

Stopped by here while at the Marriott or a conference. It's a nice spot. The staff is super, super friendly. The place is small though and gets crowded quite easily. I ordered this toast with poached eggs. It was OK. A bit bland. The coffee more than made up for it.

I was visiting SF for a week and I had to try this place out. I've heard of the brand and the 1000+ positive reviews sold it for me. When I got there, the line was out of the door and took about 10 minutes to pass through, so don't be intimidated by it. I got a Japanese style drip coffee. It was very thick and rich cold brew. It was intense but still drinkable. It was very very good and if it was affordable and living there I would definitely drink this every StaurdayI also got a Tahini cookie. Unfortunately I did not really enjoy the tahini cookie. It was too sweet and a little mealy

Blue Bottle Coffee is what I hope to find in an urban coffee shop buried in San Francisco's South Of Market district. Turns out, Blue Bottle is a local chain, started in Oakland, now sprawling the globe with over 50 locations. Despite the mold, the store we walked into provided a first-time experience for us.The atmosphere is up-cycled industrial conversion, occupying a first floor corner space in an office building on Mint Plaza that reeks of story. The line for service was literally out the door when we walked up on a typically sunny, temperate San Fran Saturday morning. Always on the hunt for something new, we ordered New Orleans Cold Brew, a swirly mixture of milk and dark and smooth cold brew that was robust without being bitter. We both normally want to sweeten our coffee. But this brew was just so good, we didn't want to alter it in any way. We also tried a Siphon Coffee, something I'd never heard of. Apparently, it uses a Japanese-manufactured device that happened to be set up directly in front of where we sat. They heat the coffee to a specific temperature and brew it directly in the water in a flask straight from high school chemistry lab without a filter, skimming the grounds when they pour it out (see my pix). It's served in a beaker with cold water to clear the pallet between sips. I don't know how different it really was (I'm a bit too hoi polloi to perceive the distinction). But, it was fun and unusual. The barista who made it for us was informative and kind enough to answer all my Siphon-newb questions.We also ordered Avocado Toast, which was exceptional. But, center stage was the coffee. High marks for service, experience, atmosphere, quality, and variety. If there was a Blue Bottle near me, I'd hit it all the time. Highly recommended!

I dare say this may be the best cup of coffee I've ever had.I was staying at the Marriott around the block and I decided to I come here before my work day begun around 8ish. I arrived to find line around the corner. Thankfully, it went quick and I was in and out within 15 minutes. I ordered the original cold brew with a bit of almond milk. After slurping it down I was decided I'd have to I return the next day and order a hot coffee. The following day I went with the caffe latte added almond milk and a bit of sugar. Oh man was I in heaven. As I walked back to work I couldn't help but wonder if I'll ever taste coffee as good as this. In that moment, nothing has or ever will stack up to Blue Bottle Coffee.
The latte was decent enough.  But the wait was on the long side.  But maybe that is how it is here.  20 minutes for a latte just doesn't cut it for me.  Maybe we caught them at an off moment.
Most amazing decaf latte I've ever had and very friendly staff. It's tucked away but don't let that stop you from getting a quality cup in SF.
Nice, rich coffee. It came quick and there were enough seats for my family. My only nitpick was that the coffee was pretty lukewarm.

I came here super excited to try their croissant after reading the reviews on it because I love alomond croissants so much (the almond paste) and I was craving sweet stress foods after finals. There were two kinds of almond croissants available that day: chocolate banana almond and raspberry almond croissant and honestly I wanted to try the raspberry almond but because of the numerous reviews on the chocolate banana one I bought it without question even though I don't really like sweet fudgy chocolate stuff I'm more of a dark chocolate kind of person. YUM: The croissant was crunchy, warm, and gooey but I didn't really like the chocolate inside. I can tell why people love it though. But I came for the sweet, yummy almond paste I love and the chocolate and banana were clearly the main thing in this croissant masking any almond paste that regular almond croissants have(if there even was any). Really love the texture of the croissant though, I enjoyed every bite. I will definitely come back to try other flavors. $4.50 is a little pricey but again it's B patisserie and the croissant was satisfying. REGRET: I did regret spending my money on this flat thing called an arlette though. It was way too sweet; just a flat crunchy churro basically with way too much surface area covered with cinnamon sugar. That $3 could've been better spent on another croissant. I only bought it out of curiosity, asking a worker what is this? and I asked her if it was good and she said oh it's SO good. I am too easily convinced. I will be back to try a different croissant though! In the meantime I shall save up my food funds.

Here's what I had from b:- Kouign Amann- Almond cake- Passion fruit bostock- Mushroom tartine (apparently an open faced sandwich)The total came out to like $35, so save your money folks. Of course there was a line when I went Saturday at 4 pm but it moves quickly, although several items were out (I really wanted a chocolate croissant).The Kouign Amann was ridiculous and clearly the best pastry item I had. In my friend's words, "they've got their pastry crunch and flake game on point," and I wholeheartedly agree. Next time I'm just going to stuff my face with as many Kouign Amann I can afford to buy ($4.25 each yo).The tartine was $11, and when I went to eat it at a nearby park, the wind may or may not have blown the takeout box so that the mushroom and cheese fell onto the grass while I was trying to take a picture of it (key word being *trying*). But I'm not one to waste food so if that did happen, I would have scooped it up and eaten it all the same. Either way it was delicious.
What can I say? The pastries are all awesome. Chocolate banana croissant is outstanding. Pick up a few pastries and order a green tea. Then soak up the local atmosphere:)

Hands down one of the best bakeries in the bayTheir kouign amann is to die for. Their other pastries are equally amazingA friend and I once sat down to get the sandwiches and I was shook by the presentation of the food. The flavors were amazing and I couldn't believe we weren't actually at a restaurant. Absolutely love this place.

If you like bananas, chocolate, almonds, and croissants, then the banana chocolate almond croissant is just for you. That is my go to pastry when I come here. Their croissants are so flaky and buttery. I'm drooling just thinking about it. I'm not craving a croissant. That's how good they are.If you are nearby, GO HERE AND ORDER SOME PASTRIES!

Popped in on a weekday morning and it was crowded! Even so, the lines moved fast and someone attended to us very quickly. I got the giant white chocolate and valrhona cookie - good texture, not too sweet. I also ordered a flat white to go. Decent coffee to pair with pastries. I really liked the atmosphere here.

KOUIGN AMANNS! Get them! You will not be disappointed. I got the Vanilla, Chocolate, and Strawberry Rhubarb and they are out-of-this-world amazing. I bought one of each on my first visit, then went back for more a couple of days later because I could not stop thinking about them! They have a buttery, flaky exterior with a creamy, soft inside and are not too sweet. If I had to pick a favorite flavor, it would have to be Vanilla. I also tried their Chocolate Banana Almond Croissant, Chocolate Caramel Toffee Mousse, Passionfruit Bostock, Raspberry Matcha Cake, and Black Sesame Latte. They were good, but I probably would stick to the Kouign Amanns next time. Prices are comparable to other bakeries in the city (but they charge $0.10 for a paper bag with handles). The interior is simple with marble countertops. There is some seating inside and out, but only street parking available. Although the line is usually long, it moves quickly, as there are many employees.

Almond croissant or a kouign amman.. you can't go wrong with either!! Hands down the best French pastry place in SF. I like going on a weekday, grabbing a table facing the street and imagining that everybody around me is speaking French and I am facing the Jardin de tulleries!!

We came for the kougin amann ends, but unfortunately they said it wouldn't be available until 12pm. However after one bite of the kougin amann, we got back in line and ordered more pastries to try and some to bring home. Everything was good and I would definitely go back here the next time I go to SF.

Okay, kick me because I'm wrong. B Patisserie has delightful pastries. It's been a long time since I sat and ate pastries at the cafe. The last time was when there was only their original space. Now that they acquired and opened  up more space it feels like there's more elbow room and I can breath.Yesterday, I met a friend for a breakfast of pastries. Hey, I can't get myself out of bed and home very quickly in the morning so in truth it was closer to lunchtime when we got to the cafe. An open table? I'm surprised! Snapped that up pretty quick and then we were able to sit down and get down to business. The business of eating pastry!I got a chocolate kougin amann and a banana chocolate almond croissant. My friend got a plain croissant and scarfed that down quickly. Appalled (that's no way to appreciate good pastry!) I gave her bits of both my pastries. She's never been to b patisserie before so I'm trying to clue her in on the goodies here.She likes them but then she fesses up that she's on a diet. Say whaaaaat?This friendship is not going to last if she doesn't eat while I sit there like a starved cat with a platter of cream in front of my face.Well, I took away most of my croissant for eating later but that kougin amann was history in no time. Buttery, flaky and just the right balance to the Valrhona dark chocolate. The latter was just too good!Now if only they could tune down the bass to their shop music I'd enjoy my dining experience so much more!

It's definitely worth the hype!  I'm surprised that there's not an hour long line out the door every day at this place.  But I guess lets keep it that way! I tried their mango coconut croissant and it was amazing.  I never thought I would have another memorable croissant until trying this one.  It may be a seasonal flavor but I don't think you'd be disappointed if you were to select another specialty croissant of theirs.  Their Kouign Amanns are definitely really good.  I like how they incorporate chocolate or fruity fillings in them. They don't overfill them which is a nice way for us to enjoy the pastry itself.  The bite-sized financiers are dream explosions in my mouth as I'm typing this review.  Their Ham&Cheese sandwich as well as their Burrata/Prosciutto sandwich were also delicious.  Service was great and I really have no complaints about this place.

I haven't had the chance to try many of their pastries, but the banana and chocolate croissant is probably the only thing I'll ever want to eat. It's just one of the best croissants I've ever had - a perfect combination of flavors (if you're a fan of banana like me). Even though I'd like to review other things, I don't think I'll ever be able to choose something else.

The husband and I stopped here before a Saturday Hike! Long line -- to be expected... we chose 4 pastries to share & enjoyed each one!  My only regret is I didn't get the Kouign Amann !! Will go back for !

My ULTIMATE favorite bakeshop! Love everything sweet they have to offer. The mango, chia seed varrine is SOOOOOO delicious! The kouign amman is the best I've ever had and the chocolate chip cookie is to die for. Can't wait to try everything else!

Taste: 5Value: 5Service: goodThis place definitely lives up to its reputation. The line was short for mother's day. I was helped right away. I bought 4 pastries in total - the top 3 sellers according to the lady who helped me. I got two flavors of their signature pastry - seasonal strawberry rhubarb and chocolate kouign amann. These and tne chocolate croissant were amazing. So flaky, crunchy, and perfectly sweet. The melty chocolate was like the more delicious nutella in my mouth. Passion fruit bostock also did nof disappoint - nice fruity flavor and less sweet than the others I took home. Can't wait to come back and try more things!!

I was looking for pastries near UCSF Mt Zion and this place popped up on my search. Thanks, Yelp. I tried the chai tea and the banana chocolate croissant. While things were good, the chai was mediocre and the croissant did not seem croissant like at all. It was delicious but if they called it something else, it would've made more sense. It had more of a thin soft cookie texture outside than a croissant. It just looked like they tried to shape it as a croissant but it did not quite work out. Tasty though.

Simply superb bakery. So far, I only tried the kouign amann and the passionfruit bostock. Both were among the finest pastries I have eaten in years. Definitely crave-worthy. Special bonus is that the line moves faster than you think!

Whenever I make any trip to San Francisco, it always has to include a stop at the one and only B. Patisserie. A one of a kind bakery in The City that speaks at it's own high level of quality and expertise at making pastries beyond your typical pastries at a bakery/coffee shop. When you come to B. Patisserie, there are only 2 things that a true fan must order first before anything else: Kouign Amanns and Passion Fruit Bostocks. After that, go for some other varieties of Kouign Amanns, delicate desserts, or go home with a giant artisan loaf or French bread. If you have never been nor heard of this place before, you must start with the 2 I mentioned before, and once you do, you will never forget how wonderful B. Patisserie's pastries truly are. They have small brunch dishes as well as coffee too but they're mostly known for their pastries so make sure you go for the pastries first. Eat there or bring home, you will be definitely enjoying your stay at B. Patisserie. Would I recommend this place to others? A definite YES!
i need to stay away from this place!  i always end up buying almost everything! this place is so good! my parents loved this place when they came visiting.  good job!

Danggg this place was good!! Overpriced.......but tasted great. The Kouign Amman is what they are known for. I got the chocolate one, but I wish I had gotten the original instead. I also got the raspberry matcha pastry. Delicious!
