used to be my go to place...i know it is pricey...but yesterday took the cake - long lines, 14 minutes to get my drink...surly staff...totally confused...and then i got back in line for a donut (my son asked me...otherwise, i would not have gotten anything) and the pastry bin was full of fruit flies.  not one or two but dozens.  i think the owner is too busy opening new locations to focus on the details...oh and the donut was $5.  $5 for a donut. i have now seen it all... so now i gotta find a new hang out in mv when i am seeking coffee and sunshine.  cool place and proof lab is awesome!

Great place to stop before or after a bike ride. They have a lovely outdoor patio, and really relaxed vibe. I accidentally spilled a coffee all over and one of the baristas Steven was nice enough to clean it up and brew me another delicious cup!It has a familial feel to it, and lots of affluent, friendly Silicon Valley people frequent the cafe. And obviously the coffee is phenomenal

Not impressed. Overpriced coffee made by pretentious hipster baristas that have their own idea of how coffee should be served rather than listening to how you'd like it.  I was soo hopeful and ultimately soo disappointed.

The coffee and staff are so great that when I go to Marin from San Francisco I always stop for a latte (sometimes both ways) and get my beans from there to have at home & go through that every 2 weeks for years. The staff is super knowledgeable & friendly and they even have dog bowls outside. I've hung out in the outdoor seating with my mom's dog after picking her up from doggie daycare next door and staff was really friendly.

I drove almost an hour out of my way to go to this cafe that I found on Yelp, searching on "coffee shop" and "dog friendly" and "free wifi."  The options were limited for north of San Francisco, and this was the closest.  Took the hour to get here, so I could work on a computer with wifi access, while babysitting a rescue dog, who gets anxious when left alone.If I could, I'd deduct all 5 stars due to the woman employee who gave me a hard time about asking about their being listed on Yelp as "dog friendly."  It came up when I asked if they had any doggie biscuits - I asked another employee and she jumped in, saying they don't have dog treats and made some crack about most dogs being gluten intolerant (not all dog treats have gluten, lady) and told me that although the dog was cute, it could not be inside.  I mentioned that the cafe was listed as dog friendly on Yelp and she and the others said they knew nothing about that but there was a water bowl in the parking lot area.I was standing in line and had already paid for the beverage (otherwise I would have just left). I took the dog outside, where the only place to sit is a few tables in the parking lot.  I got only a few minutes of work done, when the same employee came out and took photos of the dog - outside -  WITHOUT MY PERMISSION.  I was so creeped out by this that I left as soon as she did that and threw away the overpriced beverage.Very upset to be treated that way after researching and coming specifically to this cafe, and then be ridiculed for asking about dog treats, then have them "document" the dog by taking photo without permission.  The experience left me shaken and basically ruined my afternoon.  A coffee shop should not leave you feeling violated for bringing a dog when Yelp search  lists it in results for "dog friendly."

The laundromat has CLOSED! Though you can still get coffee.I have been coming here for at least 5 years. Just another bit of old San Francisco disappeari... well, I know it's not the Elbo Room or Kink, but this little place had a piece of my heart. It was clean, convenient, quiet. The kind of laundromat you could bring your laptop or a book on a dark winter night and shelter inside as your clothes were made new again. A lot of the machines seemed to be broken, but you could always find one. Thank you, Spin City, for doing all my pants, shirts, gym clothes, socks and even my dogs' disgusting beds. Guess I have to find somewhere else now. Or maybe even  - gulp - buy my own washing machine. It's just so sudden...
Excellent coffee and great service! Perfect Sunday morning coffee spot. I'm sure I'll be back here often. Wish they stayed open later than 5pm. It's my new favorite coffee spot in Noe Valley.

As a open window walkup cafe this is good, and I like the donut, the well-lighted interior and my expresso. But my god, if you are a laundromat you need to be either cheap OR YOUR MACHINES NEED TO WORK. We encountered problems constantly, from washers that eat quarters but don't start (2x) to dryers that spin with no heat (2x). Whole experience was a joke of having to ask for help multiple times from the expresso crew, multiple refund requests and an hour extra of waiting. 2 stars for cafe, 0 stars for laundromat.

Most of the machines I tried--among those that didn't have out of order signs on them--did not work. The machines are old and clearly poorly maintained. Hair and dust everywhere, at least in the laundromat section. Understaffed, so it took a while to get help with the machines. No working plugs to use for charging devices. Coffee was just fine, and there's an interesting selection of pastries, but I wouldn't come back.

I have gone to this little coffee shop a few times. My first time was really nice and the taste was very fresh. Since then, I think the quality has gone down a bit. It's always busy when I have gone and sometimes the barista is nice but not always. I do see a lot of regulars that do go to this coffee shop more than the crappy Martha's. I always get the mocha with their dairy free milk which the oat milk is my favorite. I don't like how the oat milk is a hit or miss there as the last few times I have gone, they didn't have any oat milk. I think their drinks are on the small side but I think it's because it's more a hippie European coffee shop. I feel like they should get a larger size and still have their traditional regular size. The price has recently gone up as well which I know how expensive it is within the neighborhood but I'm not sure how fast I will be back for a cup of coffee unless I'm really craving a mocha and they have oat milk. I never tried their doughnuts/sweets there so I'm not sure if it is good to try or not. I would definitely pick this shop over Martha's as I just despise Martha's coffee/mochas.

It's been a real pleasure to watch the coffee bar start from a tiny corner and take over most of the launderette :) I've always enjoyed coming to the coffee bar. They were ahead of the curve with introducing oat milk, and Maricar (or any of the other cool baristas) is always warm and friendly.

We've been coming to Spin City for almost 5 years now. Although we don't come here for the laundry facilities anymore, we still come here for the cute atmosphere, delicious coffee, and the friendly owner (and barista!) in the heart of Noe Valley.
This is a sort of a hybrid of coffee shop and laundromat. I came to try the coffee and it was delicious. I enjoyed the flavorful mocha with almond milk.

Came here the other day with my boyfriend after being away for the holiday and in the desert for some camping. We have laundry in our building but it was super convenient to use the larger washers and dryers. About $5 for a large heavy duty wash. The laundry side is a little neglected but we really enjoyed the coffee selection and blueberry muffin. 5 stars all around because this place does what it needs to do, with available bathrooms, detergent vending machines, large washers/dryers, quarter dispenser, and spot on coffee+baked goods! I will share a small story though which I feel has nothing to do with deducting stars and hate when I see reviews where people take away from the business because certain clientele are inappropriate. A hippy looking, 40+ woman, with glasses approached me claiming I was killing her with my detergent. She then went on a rant as I continued to just sit and smile to not escalate her demeanor. What honestly is so shameful of the situation is that I am open to hearing and learning about organic products and how to be a better person to my environment. I ended up purchasing what she had recommended but in the end I feel the world would be a better place if we kept in mind that being right doesn't always mean you need to sacrifice being kind. During her rant I was told that shopping at Gus market is totally foul, that rainbow market is the last good piece of San Francisco, and even mocked for not knowing its location off the top of my head. Hopefully my review doesn't keep from going to Spin city. Enjoy a cup a coffee while your clothes clean. Stay away from Tide! And be in bliss with your blueberry muffin :)

NOLA Coffee (iced coffee, almond milk, half/half) Stumbled upon this coffee shop while visiting another establishment. Very cute place. Hipster sort of vibe. Coffee was reasonably priced - the barista explained the menu and was super polite. Plenty of parking which is a plus! I will certainly be back :)

ive done my laundry here for years. But, due to the old machines, broken dryers and general neglect of the laundry area I'm moving on. The owner is obviously only focusing on and maintaining the cafe part of this location. I wouldn't really call it a laundry mat anymore.

A great little cafe situated in one corner of a laundromat. I never thought I'd be a fan of any eatery located inside of a laundromat, but I was wrong. I've been here about a dozen times.The lattes and coffee are solid (good but not the best I've ever had). The cafe has a wide selection of base goods, including gluten free Dynamo Donuts! The Lemon Powered Donut is amazing.

This has been my go-to laundromat for years, but recently they have seriously gone downhill as they seem to be catering more to their coffee customers than to people who actually go there to do their laundry. They removed the counter where you fold your clothes and replaced it with tables and chairs, and then removed a bunch of washing machines and replaced them with a counter with chalkboards on the front. If you try folding your clothes here, you'll get chalk all over the front of your pants! Whose bright idea was this??There are always several washers and dryers out of order, including the 50 lb. washer that I like to use, which has been out of commission the last several times I've visited.Oh, and the barista has a bit of an attitude. I once heard her tell a customer who ordered a fancy drink that maybe she ought to go to Starbucks instead!

Excellent coffee and pastries. I did get 2 Canadian quarters (which don't work in my laundry machine) while breaking a $20 for quarters using the machine in the back, but I think the coffee and the convenience of being able to get change while sipping a delicious cappuccino more than makes up for it.

This review is for the coffee shop -- this is the third time I've been here where they serve the people after me in line because those people are regulars and/or know the owner by name.  I would love to keep coming here since it's just around the corner, but waiting for your drink after the people behind you in line receive theirs isn't worth the $4 pour over.

Very friendly and outgoing young lady who works here and like the ability to get a hot beverage and donuts while I do the laundry. The only real issues quite a few broke units dryers and the Giant Loader will come back like the feel of the place which is due to a great employee who call you by your name and makes you feel welcome.

I don't know WHO is running this place now. They removed around 4 washing machines to add a kid drawing board?! It's not a daycare!!! There is NO free WiFi not ONE SINGLE outlet for you to charge ur phone!!! Who does that?! At least a third of the machines are broken down .....but if I want good coffee and doughnuts.....this is the place for you! But good luck getting laundry done!! Ridiculous!! Last time I come spend my $$ here.

I have used this laundromat weekly for over a year, but it has really gone downhill recently.  Half the smaller washing machines have been removed, the folding area has been ripped out, and half the machines no longer work, and are mostly not labeled as such.  I wasted so much money on dryers that produced no hot air last time that I will not be returning.  One reviewer mentioned that some of the washing machines are full of filthy water/sludge.  This is true, the owner knows about it, and tends to let them sit like that for weeks on end.  She used to have them repaired, but last time so many washers were gone/out of order that my 4-5 loads of laundry used every available, working machine.  The coffee and snacks are good, and I like the owner, but the current situation is untenable for me.  Might return for coffee, but that's it.

It was a confusing visit today. I arrived to see they'd removed half of their smaller washers and replaced the large stainless steel folding area with tables for drinking coffee at. They seem to have put some sort of bare wood counter where the washers used to be, but it's also a chalkboard for the neighborhood kids. It feels like this is a clear message that this is not a place for people like me who go there to do laundry. The wood is less than sanitary and I don't want chalk on my clothes or little kids under my legs.I understand it must be nice to be a part of the  neighborhood, with families stopping by with kids and dogs to buy coffee (who all comment how they love the tables, yet do not sit at them), so maybe that's why they are focusing their business on the coffee part. Because I can't do laundry here anymore, there is no space to fold anything if there are more than two other people doing laundry in there besides you. :(

This is no longer a laundromat. It is a coffee shop with a few sporadically working machines. And calling them 'working' is giving them credit. Over the years, I've probably lost $50 because the dryer doesn't heat, washing machine didn't spin, or it didn't have hot, or even warm, water. Reviews here that are 4-5 stars are for the coffee...which, fine. But anyone who actually does their laundry here doesn't care about all that. They just want a machine that cleans, rinses, and dries their clothes. If the owner simply wants to be a coffee shop, then just do it. Stop half-a**ing the laundromat, or let someone else manage it, because you are definitely not.

Try the kale salad. Martha makes it, and it is pure bliss. Insane! This business is what SF businesses used to be like. They have maintained their culture and it's no bravado in the gold rush of SF. Thank you!
I've lived in Noe for 8 years. If they don't know you here they give you the cold shoulder. Just had my last straw with it.

Ok it's a coffee shop so let's start with the coffee. Locally roasted and served fresh - delicious!  Bold or mild you choose. They will all delight you.  Want a specialty drink? They got you covered. The baristas know what they're doing. They are friendly and no nonsense in a good way. This place isn't about the frills. Great coffee, superb fresh-baked treats, and friendly service. Grab it to go, sit outside, watch the world turn, and savor the moment. Enjoy!!
Consistently best  coffee in San Francisco served with a smile Great speciality blends they will mix on requestReal neighborhood gem.

This Martha's is a nice alternative when my corner Martha's is way crowded, I need to do some errands on 24th or I just feel like a nice walk up to 24thUsually greeted by lots of sidewalk doggies & this is part of the appeal for me!Coffee beans will be ground to my specifications & their mochas are like rocket fuel & this is a very good thing!Their pastries are constantly fresh & I always see new introductions of items to temp savory & sweet tastes alikeAns this definitely makes Martha's as good as it gets

I've been coming here for more than 30 years but hadn't been in a while. It was so nice to walk in yesterday to see that Martha's is still down-to-Earth and local and humble and wonderful. Delicious coffee for $2.50, interesting community characters still loafing around with everyone knowing each other and chatting together across tables and sharing jokes and John's terrific mural still up on the wall. Martha herself hasn't aged a day in twenty years and they're still an 'everybody' coffee shop as opposed to one of those barren hipster places. It was a great relief to see that all of this is still alive and well on 24th Street. I am grateful.

Convenient location and spacious place. I tried their iced coconut latte, and it was amazing. From the exterior, I did not expect much but I left with a happy tummy and satisfaction  :) Their pastries and desserts looked fresh and delicious as well, I'd have to come in again and try. Thanks Martha for this nice experience!

5 stars if they didn't mess up an order.Lots of good coffee, tea and drink choices along with sweet and savory breakfast and lunch options.My brother in-law tried the coconut milk iced coffee but it tasted off so asked for something different. When he asked for a latte they made it iced (but that wasn't what he ordered). Oy veySome tables inside and several outside when the weather is good.Would definitely come back as the employees are nice and coffee (I had a cappuccino) is good

Started going here recently after starting a job in the area, so I am here 2-3 times a week now.  I no longer go to the Starbucks nearby and come here instead for mainly two reasons: 1.  Starbucks does not carry sugar-free hazelnut syrup for coffees; I need to watch my sugar intake so I was super happy when I found out Martha's carries it.  2.  My Americano order comes to me steaming hot (how I like it!). Even after I add cream, I still have a hot cup of coffee, opposed to a warm cup like at Starbucks.  They must heat their water to a higher temperature or something.  They have an AWESOME selection of really great pastries and breads; I usually get the banana bread.  They have outside seating so you can go outside and enjoy your coffee in the sun.  Their staff is also wonderful.

By far the worst coffee in Noe Valley. No idea what is going on with the positive reviews. The neighborhood is  charming yes, but let's not give this shop credit for that. I've lived in the neighborhood for 10 years and I end up trying this spot a couple times a year thinking it can be as bad as I recall, but it is. The coffee always tastes burned and the staff, while pleasant, always seems a bit befuddled about how to go about their jobs.  Pastries are just okay at best--and are often stale or disappointing.
I stopped by for a muffin and coffee but left without finishing either. My muffin was nearly frozen stuff and tasted like it came from Safeway, and the latte was scalded and just tasted bad.

One of the most local, humblest places you can go to for a small coffee. That's it. That's my yelp review. But seriously, great staff members and customer service. Coffee drinks are unique (coconut milk latte with strong amount of coffee), quality is decent, pricing is budget friendly (which was the most surprising of all).

Apparently some places in Bernal Heights have the gall of closing shop in the afternoons when I'm starving and looking to load up for a picnic. Enter Yelp, its life saving recommendations, and Martha & Brothers. My crew loaded up on their prepared foods and I got the coconut cold brew because apparently being an adult means you're exhausted if you get to bed after 9pm. The coffee was incredible and unique. The coconut flavor cake through heroically; not overpowering the coffee but shining bright like a diamond. It was just sweet enough and gave me the kick in the pants I needed to hike up to Bernal Heights Park. We stopped right as wen entered and split one of the burritos because my husband was hungover and crumpling like ball of foil and I had no excuse. The burrito was fantastic: all the ingredients tasted fresh and even though it was pre-made it wasn't soggy. We hiked a bit more and hit up the two salads we bought, curried chicken salad and Greek. The ingredients were so fresh, the greens were super flavorful and fresh, they both were really filling with lots of protein, bright flavors, and various textures. I was really impressed and can't wait to go back to hit on some of those baked goods.

short line in the afternoon...taking a coconut almond milk latte and a chocolate cheesecake cupcake...few minutes and ready...space is small and tables are cramp, but finding a place to sit...coconut almond milk latte was great...tasty latte with subtle coconut flavors....highly recommend getting it...the chocolate cheese cupcake was extremely sinful...delicious thick chocolate cheesecake inside...moist and good...

Great staff. Seriously! Super yummy treats, too. Mediocre coffee, though, especially their cold brew. It's disgusting. My work will sometimes bring in coffee from different places in unmarked containers. Whenever it's from Martha's, I can tell immediately... and when I ask, sure enough, it's Martha's.

I'm with the other five star reviewers.  I've been coming here for 20 years, and no other coffee tastes as good to me.  It is NOT burnt tasting, folks!  I always get the Red Eye, packs a punch and delicious.  Lots of good food, and friendly & familiar staff with ultra low turnover.  A beloved Noe Valley institution.

I'm obsessed with this place! It's a shame that as an SF born and raised individual, I never knew about this company. However, I am glad that I found it jus a week ago (better late than never). The employees are friendly, the food is tasty, and the coffee has always been fresh throughout my visits! What caught my attention were the PLENTY of glass cases containing various homemade goodies (crumb cake, almond chocolate cake, pumpkin cheesecake, etc.)  Although it was a tough decision I chose the almond chocolate. It was moist, fresh, and to my surprise had some cream cheese lining between the chocolate and almond bread! So good!My usual here is the iced mocha with almond milk and whipped cream. It never disappoints. I'll definitely be coming back regularly. :)

Loved my time here! Came in on a Monday and stayed for a few hours to get some work done! Chill and quiet atmosphere perfect for some alone time. Iced coffee was also great as well, although it needed a bit of sugar.

Of all the Martha's locations in the city, this one is my favorite.The employees are super friendly, and they make good coffee and food. I have had not so great experiences at their Cortland St location, but the employees here are always so nice, no matter how busy it is which I can't say the same for the other location.If you stop by, get one of their bagels!! So good!
The perfect neighborhood coffee house-great coffee, good pastries-breakfast bagels. Wonderful service-Martha herself is an institution.

First time at Philz, ordered a mint mojito for myself and a tesaro mocha for my husband. My mint mojito was refreshing and just right  amount of sweetness at medium. I sampled my husband's mocha and it was also good. Thanks to the guy on the Muni who recommended the mint mojito.

Finally tried Philz for the first time here! Almost every other customer order I heard getting called out is a mint mojito, so obviously that seems like a good choice!Mint Mojito || S ~$4.95Muddled sugar and mint leaves with coffee, heavy cream, ice, and more mint leaves on top. I heard this drink is supposed to be extremely creamy, but I actually find it a bit more watery. I think I would ask to get it creamier next time if I get this again. It's definitely a tasty and unique drink. I can see why people enjoy it. It's just not quite as "omg wow amazing" for me as many people have hyped it out to be. Due to the price point for a small cup, this place might be more of a once in a while treat for me. I would visit again though. The mint mojito is nice to try at least once.

WOW, this coffee is incredible! I normally stick to lattes, but their drinks are amazing! Subtle on the sweetness, strong on the flavor. Definitely get the Gingersnap, and if you want another drink, try the Mint Mojito (with ample mint leaves upon mint leaves within). Clearly high-quality drinks made with skill.

Excellent service. Excellent coffee, as always. Sunday late afternoon crowd just showed up and only one barista working while the other was on break  poor girl. She was super nice and kept cool. Just wish the customer in front of me didn't order 6 different coffees

The first time I tried Philz, it was in this location. So convenient from the Embarcadero station heading to the Ferry building. The coffee here is so well crafted. No need to add your own cream or sugar, they do it all for you. Be sure to pick the type of coffee you would before approaching the crafty barista. They'll ask you the level of sweetness you would like. After your order is placed, all you have to do is pay. They'll call you when it's done. If it's not to your liking, they adjust whatever you need.The staff is friendly and offerings in snacks/pastries are good, but not amazing.

Pretty large area, but not a lot of indoor seating/tables.  Baristas were super friendly, checkout staff could use more smiles.As always, coffee and food quality were top notch.Couple bums hanging around inside, but not bothering anyone.  Smelled a little less than fresh, kinda surprised the staff didn't boot them.  Maybe they are regulars?Overall, nice location, just expect everything SF has and all will be kosher.

The mint mojito iced coffee lives up to ALL the hype. I don't know what magic they use to make it so delicious and creamy. The fresh muddled mint in it also adds such a nice touch, versus using an artificial mint syrup.

If there was another decent coffee option it would win this area hands down. Coming in here is like walking into the Seinfeld episode of the Soup Nazi. Super intense. Yesterday I was the only person in line, but I wasn't standing in the right place. This morning, there are 5 baristas. Not 1 order is taken for ever and the line is 30 people deep and keeps building. Just goes to show it's all about location. Please please improve your service and hire a great ops person.

Philz Coffee - Embarcadero, marks the 5th Philz I've been to and guess what? The coffee is just as amazing as all the other locations. Large Ecstatic - My go to, my coffee love, my coffee everything. Coffee love at first sip kinda gig you know?Lines are long but the baristas are super quick and friendly too!This Philz is larger than average. There's plenty of seating for those who would like to stay and definitely a lot of room to accommodate the line. Yaaaaaaaas Philz, thanks!

Love this location! Being in such a busy area, the lines aren't that long because these guys know how to get it done fast without compromising quality. Philharmonic and Ambrosia are my favorite blends, and paired with an avocado toast it's practically perfect in every way

Yaaaaaaz -- Moving to SF, I definitely became a coffee fan, all due to Philz Coffee. I recommend the Philharmonic for mint and cardamon. And if you feel like spending more,get the gingersnap with cardomon.And if you are hungry, I recommend getting the Avacado Toast with egg. And if you're concerned about carbohydrates, get the Avacado Energy Bowl instead.

Philz will always have my heart! Everytime I'm in the Bay Area I make sure to get it a couple times a day. It's so good! There's always a bit of a line, but download the app and save yourself some time! My favorite is the philharmonic with light cream. I had the iced rosé special today to mix it up and was pleasantly surprised! The rose and beet are a great addition and don't overpower. If you're a coffee lover, definitely take the time to check out Philz!

I like this location too.  I came here couple times in the morning and in the afternoon, they got my coffee right every time...temperature, taste, and sweetness.  A good cup of cafe makes a big difference in my day.   :))
This is the third time that I went into Philz coffee and they don't have begals after a certain time I think  they should serve their customers. And the one close by has the similar issue. Lame

What a great place to start your mornings at! These guys will definitely lift your spirits on any morning. As soon as you walk in, they greet you and are super friendly when they take your order. I got the Philtered Soul and an almond croissant, both were very delicious. Their store is extremely clean and spacious. I was glad to get at the store when I did because when I was paying for my drink, the line was almost out the door! It seemed like you can make mobile orders if you are in a hurry though. The coffee = STRONG AF. I'm a 5'0 little lady, and that drinkg gave me the jitters. I definitely shouldn't ever order a large here. They ask if you want cream and sugar if you prefer to not have your coffee black, like me. It was definitely a different taste of coffee than I've ever had.The food = Delicious almond croissant, you can always ask to get your pastries warmed. I really wanted to try their avocado toast because it looked so delicious! I will have to come back to try.The environment = Clean, chill, and roomy. There are plenty of seats inside, including a sofa. A lot of people here were on their laptops or just chatting with some friends. Very relaxing, and a great place to start your morning nice and slow.

Amazingly high quality coffee and tea.   All coffee is made 'pour over' style and is strong and delicious.  Food was also quite good.   Only reason for 4 stars is the value...at $4.70 for a large coffee it's pushing the 'OK, that's getting offensive' button.Price not considered I would give it 5 stars

It's Philz! Yay!Usually there's 3-4 baristas working here. Sometimes there can be a wait, but I'm normally able to get in and out within 15 minutes (including time to heat up breakfast).Location is set up well to facilitate the line that inevitably builds up. I like the bench seating while you wait.
Coffee was good but when you ordered from the food section it was awful. They say made fresh but they just heat up from premade packages. My burrito was grease wrapped in a tortilla.

One of my favorite Philz stores in SF. The store is beautiful, well organized, pleasant to lounge around and do work in. What REALLY makes it for me here is the baristas. I especially love Adam and Natalie, they're both super fun and always makes sure my drinks are right! I like the music they play and for being a busy coffee shop, the bathrooms are relatively clean. I love the mint mojito, the ginger snap (both iced), Tesora, Philtered Soul etc. As for food, I like the vegetable quiche (be careful, it's super hot!) This would've been a 5 star review, except sometimes it's slow and it seems like they don't have enough people for the volume of customers they get. It's a pretty big Philz RIGHT across the Ferry Building, so sometimes it gets quite busy (even on the week days).
Lol it takes 30 minutes to get a small mint mojito. It was good tho but like, come on bruh.
The pastries and sandwiches are quite good, a bit pricey but well made. The coffee is horrible though. Used to be be
Slow, indifferent service. Rather expensive prices, relative to quality.  Very slooooooooow preparation.

I have been coming here for years now? Where Did the friendly, happy people go? Or the fresh baked goods? A photo of the food wont change your attitude. Also they are always out of potatoes, but today when I went in there were MANY bowls of potatoes being photographed and I was informed they were out of potatoes by the very unhappy looking lady. The pastries I got instead were definitely not freshly baked, and the quality has diminished from my last visit (also out of potatoes then)

If you like your espresso a little extra bitter and pout with your puff pastry try this place. It sure has changed over the past long time I've stopped in here while visiting friends in the neighborhood. I bought the tomato and goat cheese quiche it was tasty and fresh when I bought it the other day. Today it seemed like someone with less skill produced the tough pastry and the bottom was soggy. Not great. The woman at the counter seemed to be having a bad day... both of the days I stopped in this week. Lots of room for improvement.

This was a great spot to go and do work today. There were plenty of tables available for a Monday morning. They have wifi, which was nice since I needed to do work on my laptop. There was a lot of natural sunlight for the rainy day it was. They have a bunch of fun pre-packaged drinks in a cooler next to the register. I chose to the get the chai one. I normally don't like chai, but I really like this one. I got the corn and poblano quiche. It was good, but I was expecting more flavor and spice.

My friends and I came here for brunch, the place looks really cute and the staff was friendly, but unfortunately the service was awful.We ordered a total of 9 dishes. They were highly disorganized and they kept forgetting to make our meals. We had to remind them about 7 to 8 times about our missing food. When we looked into the kitchen, the kitchen staff were standing around and talking or just walking around without purpose.I also paid $20 for an LB Breakfast and coffee, I will say that the pomme tots were really good, the eggs were essentially raw. It's a shame because they're in such a cute location in a busy area, but they really need some serious training or organization to make this restaurant work.
This place is authentic. The "large" vanilla bean latte is a bowl of delicious milky sweetness- I highly recommend you treat yourself to that!

The food is great! They run out of the potatoes a lot. The coffee however, is hit or miss. 60% of the time it's just burnt milk overpowering any flavor of coffee. If they could up their coffee game - I'd frequent more.
Service is par but the sandwiches/pastries especially the bread pudding and coffee are tasty!
This is probably my new favorite breakfast place. I love fresh pastry and just the atmosphere. This specific place in Cole Valley is just cozy and warm. I keep coming back.
One of my favorite cafe shops in San Fran. So cozy cafe in a neighborhood I really like hanging out. Finally they started to offer free WiFi to their customers.
The Boulangerie was much better before it was bought by Starbucks. It now feels and tastes like it's lost it's soul. Sad.

Ordered the french onion soup and was told by the cashier/server that it would come with a side of "toasted bread". Received the soup, which wasn't well prepared, and there wasn't any toasted bread in sight. It was basically a tall cup--not bowl--of microwaved soup, with commercial quality shredded cheese floating in the soup (not baked on top) and 2 small pieces of cubed french bread (see image). For $11, definitely not worth it. To make matters worse, I asked the server about the toasted bread. She gave me a bit of attitude, walked into the kitchen, came back out, took a sip of her iced coffee by the bread station, and just stood there. I caught her attention with a "where's my bread" look. Turns out she completely forgot and then started toasting some bread. After 5+ minutes of waiting, she finally brings it over and says that they usually don't do this, and said it was on the house as if she were doing me a favor and not holding herself accountable for what she incorrectly mentioned about the soup coming with toasted bread. Not coming back, nor recommending this over-rated, over-priced establishment.

I was so excited to see La Boulangerie was open when I returned to the city.  I had lived near the Sunset location and was sad when it closed.  Today, I can't express how disappointed I was in the Cole location The line was long and slow til 75% of it walked out without ordering.  When I got to the front I was informed the internet was down and they could only take cash.  I dug in my purse and found enough money to order coffee and a pastry.  I handed over a $20 and  had to wait another 5 min for someone to get a key for the cash register.  When I inquired about the amount charged, the barrista became agitated, scolded and reprimanded me and then ridiculed me to next customer as I stood there shocked.  I was humliated and told her I was an old customer happy to see the restaurant return but it was not ok to speak to me as she had and that it left a bad impression.    I took my now cold pastry and cup full of foam and left.  I will NEVER return.

A lovely café in the middle of Cole Valley - you may have to drive a few blocks to find parking. There are some good times to arrive, like just before school gets out on a weekday afternoon (1-2pm). Come then and you 'll have your pick of tables. However, wait an hour or two and you'll have to contend with crowds of strollers, backpacks and small kids! (Which isn't a bad thing unless they get to all of the cookies before you.) Early in the morning is also a mad rush for coffee.Things to order: we love their egg sandwiches, served all day long piping hot. Try the egg and arugula sando, served warm and sunny side up, with aioli, pesto, and avocado. Their pastries are also delicious, like the chocolate croissant and fresh baked cranberry bread. Do not miss the chocolate sea salt cookies, and always request that they be warmed up... Tastes like it just came out of the oven!! Prices are a bit steep but dems da breaks when you're in SF!!

This is my favorite cafe in San Francisco - they offer the best Almond Latte in giant bowl, the Goat cheese quiche will curl your toes and everything on the menu is delicious. The staff are super friendly and vibe is always good.  They finally got it together and offer wifi too... so what more do you want?
Love it here.  The salads are huge and the pastries are delicious.  Free Nutella, pickles, and other enhancements available where you collect your cutlery.

Got the chai latte on recommendation from girl at the counter. Regrets. It tasted so fake and artificial. There wasn't the deep cinnamony-cardommomy taste that makes it a chai latte. I asked to switch to another drink, because I was so unhappy with it. I got the caramel latte next, it wasn't strong tasting either...too milky.

Great service and today we ordered 5 different menu items (quinoa bowl, club, salmon, french onion soup, salad) and every flavor was amazing and every dish unique. I loved EVERYTHING and I am a picky eater!!

Darling little corner cafe tucked into the neighborhood. I was actually going to another restaurant I couldn't find and saw La Boulngerie instead.You order at counter--huge menu on wall--and they bring it to your table. I ordered the egg scramble with peasant bread and coffee. It was just right with lots of vegetables inside. They gave me extra avocado, too!It was a quiet, quaint space to share a conversation and a good meal. There is no parking lot, so close your eyes and find a space on the street!!

Overpriced. Poorly serviced. Overhyped tourist trap.It pains me to have to write this review. For context, I've looked forward to sampling tartine for 3 years as even though I'm a local now, I have been eating gluten-free for the last few years, and tartine bakery was not gluten-free friendly. I used to wistfully look at photos of their scrumptious looking creations during this time :(Well, now that I'm eating gluten once more this is one of the first places I thought of trying. And I can safely say I wasn't missing much.We visited memorial day weekend around 2.30pm and as usual there was a long queue, mostly tourists. Getting a table was really crowded affair and since they don't have a separate order pick up area, nobody monitoring the crowds or allocating tables, and the size of the shop is tiny, there were people waiting all around our table as we ate. Our every expression was on display as keen eyes waited for our thoughts on each dish. This is really not how I pictured trying my first croissant again.We ordered a lot of stuff for just two people. Chocolate almond croissants, morning buns, ham croissant, mushroom croquet monsieur, banana cream tart. We wanted to do the wait justice. Despite the large order, the cashier Odessa was quite disengaged and cold. Not a smile. I was further disappointed to see that everything other than the ham croissant was served stone cold. Morever, other than the morning buns which were lovely (if a bit heavy and BIG), nothing really stood out. It just felt like sense pastry sheets laid w (a lot of) butter.  The banana cream tart barely contained any toffee caramel sauce at the bottom.  The chocolate croissant was short on the chocolate. There was little delicacy to the baked goods and everything seemed to have been made with a very heavy-handed approach.We were so looking forward to this visit that the disappointment was even worse. All I came away with is "it's better to walk alone than with a crowd going in the wrong direction"!

The food was tasty. My hubby had pastrami. I had the lightest fluffiest quiche in my life. The pickled carrots were yummy ! I also had a lovely cappuccino. We took home two loaves of sourdough and impressed our neighbors who watched our house. We also had pain du chocolate and some morning buns! Awesome!

Went here last saturday afternoon. The wait was probably 15 minutes.  Got the following itemsa) Banana cream tart.  Very good.  Not the best I have had but very good nevertheless.  Mission pie might be better.b) Morning bun.  Flaky and light sugar.  Good but not amazing.c) Plain croissant.  Flaky but nothing special.  Nowhere comparable to Arsicaultd) Chocolate cookie.  Dark chocolate cookie.  Bitter and not very sweet.  First time I had a non-sweet chocolate cookie.  Undecided.Verdict: If you are not on the hype train and would like to avoid crazy lines, there are other options.

TL; DR: Fine option if you live/work nearby but otherwise, don't be taken in by the thousands of reviews (7k+ at this time). There are other bakeries more worthy of your time and money. I've been going to Tartine's here and there for 7 years, led by their reputation, convinced by the lines at the door. But after my last couple of experiences there, the love affair is over.There is always a line, even on a random weekday afternoon. Servers are expressionless if not downright surly. Prices are very high. But most importantly, the baked goods are no longer outstanding. I'm not sure if this is due to a fall in Tartine's standards, or a rise in others'. Maybe both. You can get amazing pastries and bread at Les Gourmands and, further south, Manresa Bread. PLUS: The servers don't behave like they're doing you a favor by taking your order.
Go early to avoid the line,  especially if you are visiting for a limited time.

The problem with me going to bakeries is that I tend to get too much and always shock myself at the register. Regardless, I never regret getting what I do. I would only regret not getting it to see how it tasted. In any case, this bakery always has a line but does move relatively quick. I think there was  ~25 people ahead of me and I got to the register within 15 minutes. You pretty much order on your way to the register. Along the way I got:[1] Chocolate chip cookie ($4) - It's huge, flat and delicious. I didn't think about getting it but 2 groups that were ahead of me got one and so I figure why not! No regrets! I even picked up a bag near the register.[2] Canele ($4.25) - Expensive but this is probably one of the best ones I've had. The inside is more cakey then custardy like I'm use to but the zesty cake flavor was soooo good and the outside wasn't that bitter. If they have any I highly recommend it![3] Gougere ($4.25) - It's like a hollow cheese bread. This was meh to me. It looked different on the inside compared to other pictures I've seen on yelp.[4] Frangipane Tart (~$8) - This was pretty good. I like the crust because it's very croissant like and the berries wasn't overly sweet. I think next time I will try the hazelnut one. I was just thrown off because the hazelnuts on top looked like corn nuts.[5] Baguette ($6) - Expensive as well but pretty good if you pair it with cheese. I prefer the softer baguettes like the ones you get with banh mi and at the Asian stores you can get them for a $1!I would have gotten a sandwich but I heard it takes about 15 minute to make. It feel very cramp and there's a fair amount of seating but not enough for my party. There's also outside seating but it was a cold day so I opted out of the sandwich. Maybe next time! I will definitely be back for the morning bun that I heard so much about and the pies looked amazing! So many good things to try and with such a small wallet I can only get so much.
Pain Au Chocolat  The Line is worth it.  The cakes are some of the most gorgeous, yet simple, classic works of art.

The bread, sweets, bone broth, everything on the menu is delicious and worth the price. I went here for a splurge one day before going keto for a month. I got tres leches cake, bone broth, bread with butter, and an olive loaf to go, for my meal (ALL THE CARBS!). Everything was fantastic.The reason I only gave 3 stars... the service here is not great. Every time I come in, the servers act like they are annoyed I am there, and roll their eyes when I ask them a question. I brought a client here for a business lunch. We were seated right away, but had to ask for service after waiting for 15 minutes. I ordered bread with butter for the table. There were 3 slices of bread with this order, and 4 people sitting at the table. When the bread arrived, I asked if we could have 1 more piece, so that everyone at the table could have some. The server rolled her eyes, before saying she would get more bread. After 10 minutes, still no bread. I asked again, and was met with another eye roll. We received our food, but still no more bread. I had to ask for the check before someone brought it. Upon inspection, I see that I was charged for the extra bread that I did not receive. The server corrected the bill when this was pointed out, but of course, this was met with another eye roll. It's like the servers here know that the bread is kick ass, so they don't even try. My advice, get a loaf to go from the bakery portion, and skip the restaurant (and the tip). Ain't no one got time or the patientce for that 'tude.

Our first time here, there was already a line winding around the corner of the store. It moved pretty fast. We ordered a Lemon cream tart - yummm, lemon berry cake - very filling, and hot chocolate - hubby loved it! If we are ever in the area, I would totally go back for the tart.

A cute, modern pastry shop tucked in on a busy street corner. There is no sign out front, so we would've missed it if it weren't for the delicious smells wafting out from the shop. Highly recommend the morning bun. It looks like a cinnamon roll that is dusted with a beautiful layer of sugar and filled with orange zest. The orange zest is soo fragrant, and you can taste it with every bite. The bun itself is surprisingly dense but still crispy on the outside. The almond croissant had layers on layers of buttery flakiness and was dusted with powdered sugar. The inside was very soft and contained a delicious almond filling. Very dense and huge, so can easily be shared by two people.
Love this place! Coffee is great, cakes/pastries are so good! And the sandwiches are even better! This place is always packed which means it's a good sign and you better check it out.
I can't understand the hype. Their pastries are good, but nothing extraordinary. Some are way too sweet. Still trying to understand what's so great about Tartine.
The morning bun, the croissants, the cookies... it's all amazing..And the morning bun!!!!!

By far one of my favorite bakeries in San Francisco. You will always find a wait here, but it's worth it!! The banana cream tarte is a personal favorite of mine but you can't go wrong with anything else. The space is small so don't expect to get a seat. I usually get some pastries and bring them to Dolores

You have to respect a place that does the basics incredibly well, doesn't jack the price up and is consistently nice to its customers. One of the few places I'm happy to line up (I think the longest I've lined up was 45 minutes).

I don't get it. For some reason it took me awhile to get over to this place and try it. I walk in and there is barely a line. I am standing looking at the pastry window for awhile. There are two workers who are talking to each other and staring off into space.  Then the line builds and then one of them finally asks if I have been helped. Guy gets my order for three cream tarts. Then I ask for two other pastries, and he didn't look happy about having to also get those things. Not a big deal, because I think to myself these pastries are probably mind blowing. Ehh. No they were not. The banana cream pie filling is good. The crust is alright. Too hard for me, and taste overbaked, close to burnt. The coconut cream pie filling was pretty good, but again the crust was exactly the same as the other pie. The chocolate croissant sucks. I felt like this was overbaked, close to burnt. Chocolate inside of it was good, but just could have spread out a little better.  And the gougere was fairly good, just not noteworthy. And again, I felt like the outside was overbaked. I had to question myself and ask "Is this what people like? Overbaked pastries, that are close to burnt? Am I missing something?" I'm sorry
A slice thin slice of cake is $7. Felt robbed. It's good but that's not saying much for a city that has many mediocre bakery/pastry shops.
Definitely worth stopping by here for even just an order of Bread and butter. EXCEPTIONAL.

SO GOOOOOD!!!!  A must-stop on my husbands list on our first trip to SF together.  Parking is tough in the area and the line outside was long so I left my husband in the car and went in to get 2 pastries... and came out with a full box.  Favorites included the Morning Bun, Almond Croissant and Ham & Cheese Croissant.  But the scones were pretty insane as well.  Will definitely return

Come for the best croissant you can imagine and delicious coffee.  All the pastries are amazing in fact.  Difficult to find a spot to eat so you might have to get things to go but Dolores park nearby is a great place to eat breakfast

So sad that there is a new owner and she discontinued the best drink/thing this place had, shaved ice with boba. I could tell you how amazing it was, how I took friends there for the drink, but why since it is gone now:(I went in last week with a friend, it was soooo hot in the shop (not using AC anymore?). The new owner looked wilted, when she told us she didn't offer the drink anymore we left, too hot to stay in the cafe to try anything else."Sad"2 stars because I want to support women in business

Stopped in for brunch on our way out of the city yesterday. We tried a couple of other brunch spots in the vicinity but all had long wait times, and just as we were about to give up and drive out of the city, we came across this quiet cafe. I ordered the meat lover's sandwich and my wife had the breakfast sandwich with avocado. Both delicious, well presented and a great deal for the price. Will defintely check this place out again next time we are in SF!

I was in the area seeking a comfortable space to sit and have a cup of coffee. I walked almost two miles to arrive and have the cashier stare me down, from the time I walked in the door until I arrived at the counter. I had to ask, "I am I in the wrong place or something?" The first thing John replied was, "We don't allow outside drinks in here," I set the now almost empty cup on the counter and said, "I walked two miles to arrive to be greeting like this?" That is when John started to explain, he had a long day and was pretty tired. I can understand that I work 12 hours days, and don't feel like smiling either, but when your job is customer service, you probably shouldn't mean mug your first-time customer. My stay was pleasant, and the place was clean; the bathroom was clean. It was a little pricey, though, but it's downtown SF. I thought John would get the message and wish me a good evening, but naw. Customer service was poor, but the place was beautiful though. I don't know if will ever return though; I like courteous service. I left wondering did this happen because I am Black, that is never a good feeling. I won't be back!

I had known about Joy's Place for a while and have even been here once before for their bingsu, but my most recent visit was for the sake of finding a good cafe to do work in. The place is simple and pretty small. The menu is also pretty small but has plenty of juicy items. This time, we went for the matcha latte and the fruit tart. Plating and presentation were cute and the treats tasted just as nice! Glad we got a tart when we could because their case sold out not too long after we showed up.I thought it was a pretty good place to study, though there was only one outlet that I could see. So if you plan to do work here, be prepared.Overall, really enjoyed the place. Would love to go back! Maybe I'll try their bulgogi sandwich by then.
Small, coffee shops style, clean, didn't see the free WiFi. I got a strawberry shortcake that was delicious and affogato (who doesn't want ice cream and espresso).

Found this place while walking towards a breakfast spot. We failed to make Rez so opted out to eating something quick here. SO GLAD WE DID. Delicious sandwiches and lattes. I had the spicy chicken (my mouth is watering just thinking about it), my friend had the salami sandwich (when finishing her first half she looked over to me and said "I don't want this to end...") overall, delicious, cheap and perfect for a quick bite.

A very quaint cafe. Stopped in for breakfast and they had both sweet and savory options which was great since my bf wanted something savory. He ordered the hot meat lovers sandwich with a espresso macchiato and was munching away happily. I ordered the cappuccino with the opera cake and having a sweet treat with the coffee provided great balance to my breakfast.
MAJOR SHOUTOUT to joys place for having a bathroom available in to their customers came in clutch for me jus now!

I know this compact cafe's been around for a while, but I never paid attention until my supposedly wind-resistant umbrella decided to resist. Not only resist but succumb and wither into a pile of Martha Graham-style dance positions. Luckily, Joy's was open, and I decided to hope for the best and wait out the torrent of wind and water outside. It's cozy and in the Tenderloin, two seemingly incompatible things that the clueless laptoppers appear to overlook with their sedentary indifference.On the chalkboard, the handwritten menu was small but delicious inviting featuring grilled sandwiches and sweet treats (photo: bit.ly/2XaScgG). Even though I found out much later that the sweet potato latte was their unique specialty, I ordered the $5 Green Tea Latte which I found soothing and satisfying (photo: bit.ly/2X4spqs). I wasn't looking forward to facing the dire elements sans umbrella, so I stuck around until a BTS-wannabe boy band or more accurately, band of boys, entered the premises at full volume. Time to go.LATTE - 4 stars...warm and entrancing as the rain fallsAMBIANCE - 4 stars...cozy and minimal on the hipster touchesSERVICE - 3.5 stars...depends on who greets you...let's face it, girls are better than boysTOTAL - 4 stars...Joy brings joyRELATED - Tiptoeing through the Tendernob? Here's a collection of places I've visited and reviewed: bit.ly/2IfTVOB

We came here for the bingsu and found out they stopped serving it a week ago! Sooo sad...but we decided to try some other stuff instead. Overall the food is very pretty but the taste isn't up to par. I would come back if they started offering shaved ice again. - Green tea latte 1/5: We got it iced. Honestly this was the biggest disappointment out of the three things we ordered because it tasted like regular milk with a very vague hint of green tea. You could barely taste the flavor of the tea. Would not recommend.- Tiramisu 3/5: Homemade. The marscapone layer makes up 80% of the tiramisu, with the remainder being a small sliver of sponge cake. It wasn't overly sweet which I enjoyed, but I would have liked more of the sponge and less of the cream.- Affogato 3/5: Vanilla ice cream with a shot of espresso poured over. Pretty hard to mess this up, so it was pretty standard.

No shaved ice like in the pics. Went at 7pm on a Wednesday and there were some desserts like strawberry shortcake, tiramisu, macarons but nothing like in the pics. Was sad about that but ordered something anyway.

The citrus honey tea, hot or cold, is fabulous!  My husband had a meat lovers sandwich.  Lots of meat, cheese, onions and tomato, and came out hot.  Really good, small but filling.  If you're not really hungry, you could share it.  Comfy, casual ambiance.  -1 star for pre-packaged pastries.

The cafe is neat and clean with some nice calm jazz playing in the background , if you come in for breakfast you can get the nice sunshine shining through the front windows, there is food as well as pastries and coffee or tea, I suggest the sandwiches which are very filling and delicious, if your looking for a good breakfast I suggest this place.

Pros: open kind of late (10 p.m.) in a place where there aren't too many other dessert options. Shaved ice portion is pretty big.Cons: shaved ice is just ok.I first visited Joy's Place on an evening to try their green tea shaved ice. We came in not that long before closing but they still made the shaved ice for us, which we really appreciated! Recently I visited again to try the honey bread, but they've stopped serving it. :( So the only item I've tried here is the:-Green tea shaved ice ($9) - as mentioned by other reviewers, the shaved ice texture is on the icy side (not my favorite). The green tea flavor is not strong, and the red bean and mochi pieces on top were also just fine.Overall it's a good option for dessert after getting dinner in Tenderloin, though they seem to be transitioning more to sandwiches now. If you want more options I'd suggest Ping Yang (their desserts are also just ok, but they have a much bigger menu and are open later).
They took away outlet accessibility =( Not an ideal update to one of my favorite go to work/study spots.

If available i would have given zero stars. Without a doubt this is the most disgusting cup of coffee I have ever had in my life. It was so bad I actually threw it in the trash. I am not sure if the milk was rancid or they just do not know how to make a café mocha. Do NOT go to Joy's Place.

Here's the breakdown:1. They have coffee drinks and desserts. I got the red bean shaved ice large ($9) and it was soft ice and very tasty!2. The cafe has roughly ~16 people sitting. I went in on a Thursday at 6:30pm and there was only one seat available but it started to empty out around 7:30pm3. The service is kind. You go up and place your order, pay up front, and come up to pick up your order. The lady who took the order was kind.4. They ran out of honey bread. Not sure if this is a permanent thing or not but it was erased from their menu board.5. The ambiance is meh. Nothing special about it. Not super cozy and beautiful. Seats are fine to sit in but nothing super comfortable.I would recommend this place for their shaved ice. Maybe a good place to go with friends or a date.

Came here a few days ago looking for a snack and some coffee and was not disappointed! I asked the barista for a food suggestion but was told that they don't eat gluten but she was happy to talk about what she noticed the crowd liked when I asked that. She also made a joke about how it was better she didn't eat bread because she would eat everything if she could! Coffee was great (had the caramel latte) and it was nice to see someone who made jokes. Definitely helped with the San Francisco rain weather.

I was looking for a hot drink and without coffee. Joy's Place fit the bill for a sweet potato latte.Ordering was quick and a grabbed a seat at the couch while the latte was being prepared. If you prefer, there are tables or a window seats available. The sweet potato latte was slightly sweet with great flavor and was spot on for me. I ended up returning on a late night for another. I have not tried any sandwiches or desserts, this will have to be a future visit
Such a little cozy place to just walk after a dinner or meal. I like their beans shaving ice cream so far. You can also bring your homework or work to finish up for the night.

Food is great! Had the Happy Hippie Bowl (vegan), banana and peanut butter toast (vegan) and matcha latte with oat milk (vegan).  All were ver delicious.Great customer service except for issues discuses below with noise. The location is not so good. Tenderloin area. Sketchy. It's the nicest restaurant in the area. Big almost floor to ceiling windows unfortunately overlooking sketchiness. The music was fine for the first 30 minutes or so then like most cafes and small restaurants, they started playing, loudly, hip hop. One song was just the "N" word over and over again. Awkward and inappropriate. I'm black and found it irritating, awkward and so inappropriate. And also, though the customer service was excellent, the staff behind the counter got super loud after a while. They were having a good time at the cost of a pleasant customer experience. I'm sure they weren't aware but I'm just sick of coming to cafes and restaurants with young staff too busy yammering on with one another that they don't know how loud they are AND how loud and/or inappropriate the music can get....I'll try Jane on Fillmore next time since I really liked the food.

Yum! Great place for a tasty, healthy breakfast. the raw sprouted black rice porridge is delish! $9, but it's a large serving of rice, oats, almond and coconut milk, coconut crunch, goji berries, raspberries, blackberries. It's just the right amount of sweetness. Def recommend!They also make a tasty latte ($9).
Just burned myself because of an improperly closed beverage container. The staff gave me ice, but still, it just spoiled the experience. To say the least.
Cap'n Crunch cookie say less... ask for Miley or Kate ... but leave Kate alone she is taken ‍

Came here for the first time recently after discovering this location! I've been to the Jane on Fillmore and was so excited to learn about this spot on Larkin.I came in on a rainy Saturday afternoon. It was pretty busy with a line out the door but I ordered at the counter and grabbed a spot at the bar and it was wonderful. Such a cute little place with the same amazing food at Jane on Fillmore. I ordered the breakfast biscuit that came on a cheddar chive biscuit with tomato jam, egg, and cheese (I ordered it without the sausage) and an iced latte. Everything was so delicious and I will for sure be back very soon!

On yelp it said they had Wifi here, but they do not! Not really conducive to studying/working here because it is a pretty small space. But, yummy food! There's also another location with the same menu on Fillmore, and a bakery location!About the food~Avocado Toast: Delicious! We ordered it on gluten-free bread, and it tastes just like normal bread! Wasn't a fan of the jalapeños but the red onions, arugula, and egg made for good toppings! The avocado mash was a little bit brown (didn't affect the taste, though).Black Sprouted Rice Porridge Bowl (hot): This is also gluten-free! TBH, it was pretty bland. We added oat milk, honey, and cinnamon to it to try to sweeten it/add flavor. The granola was good and the rice was cooked perfectly, but I also wish there were more berries on top! Service was friendly and fairly quick. You order at the counter and then sit down. They also have a huge pastry case! I wanted to eat everything in it, but my friend and I ended up sharing the GF peanut butter cookie! It was chewy and had a nice crunch of peanuts spread throughout!If you are gluten-free, Jane is the perfect place to come! About a third of their baked goods are gluten-free, and they have gluten-free bread that tastes just as good as normal bread! Also, the sun shines pretty bright through the windows here in the morning, so if you're by the window, it may get a bit hot.

As I walking to work on van ness as I do every Saturday morning I always keep an eye for good stuff. After getting off at civic center bart I decided To head down Larkin Vs. Hyde and not deal with the Hyde street circus. I was cursing to my tunes, then I see this packed cage with no markings on it. So I busted a U-turn and went it. I saw "Jane" all over the place and then the line formed and I knew I was in good hands. I came to see breakfast and coffee is their speciality and as I just started drooling over all the fresh cookies that were placing on display and all the tasty vegan baked goods that I would be embarking on. I went with the "coconut berry" vegan muffin and a coffee to go. I ended up eating inside and enjoyed the atmosphere for 15 mins, really good vibes. It was around 10:35ishAM...The vegan coconut muffin was thick, crispy on top, balanced and not greasy or under cooked. It also was a smooth taste of berry and coconut, and left me feeling good. The coffee was also very tasty and I'm a coffee connoisseur! My server was friendly and asked how I was despite the business, showed he cared.I'm excited to come back, enjoy a breakfast date with my wife.Vegans: it's deelish! -- Something for everyone and just look at the pics! There's 3 locations too...
Best Sandwich it town! Chicken mango salad sandwich and the crazy cookie it my personal favorite!

Neat spot at sort of the outer edge of the TL. I had a latte and their peanut butter and banana toast. Both were quite good, though the toast took kind of a while, which seems weird because its... toast. I think I was just more sensitive though because I was on my way to work. I'll be back to try their lunch options.

Our go-to neighborhood spot. I would say their brunch and baked goods are the best highlights on the menu in comparison to their salads and sandwiches. Our most favorite breakfast dish is the spicy baked eggs (although sometimes the toast isn't toasted long enough). We also enjoy the avocado mash toast, sausage egg biscuit, french toast, and southwest scramble. Their cookies are also really yummy especially the crazy cookie and cap'n crunch cookie. My bf likes their coffee and I enjoy the tea selections and iced matcha. They recently started adding pizza (flat bread style) to their menu and it's pretty tasty! I will also say I usually don't care for their salads but we got the A's favorite salad with pizza one night and it was surprisingly really good and filling! I would love if they could add more sandwich options. I tried the turkey panini in a recent visit and it was good but really wish the sauce had much more a kick to it.

The food and service are great! But not very optimal for working. They don't provide wifi, but they do have plenty of power outlets. So for those who don't need internet for work or don't mind using their phone hotspot. This place is okay. The music is pretty loud though, so for those who like quieter cafe. It might be not the best place to study or do their project.If you just want to come here with a friend to have brunch and chat. This cafe would be one of the best places to go

The front side of the place is super discreet. Although I love Jane the bakery. This spot is more of a sit down spot with food items and a few bakery items.The savory quinoa porridge was quiet a surprise. Poached, egg, kimchi and kale. I could see myself making this at home. The Peruvian bowl left a little more to be desired. More salad dressing maybe. The chicken was marinated well but it was a healthy boring dish for me.I really enjoyed the ham quiche. The Swiss cheese was had a nice bite to it. Got a mocha latte on ice and it reminded me of chocolate milk with a hint of coffee. All in all a good spot if you want to get some brunch without a wait but I wasn't blown away by any of this food

The space is nice and open, staff was pleasant.  We sat at the bar and it wasn't overwhelmingly busy, as mercifully we were enjoying lunch on a weekday.  I'm guessing that it gets a bit cray on weekends.My Cobb salad was pretty good, bacon could have been more luscious but I enjoyed the homemade Italian vinaigrette.If I may be nitpicky, I was disappointed in what I felt was careless preparation of my salad (and SF priced salad of course).  You'll see in the photo that my avocado looked rather unappetizing, as part of the outer skin was left intact.  Egg was clearly overcooked as well, exemplified by the depressingly gray tinge.  Will come again and hope for a more lovingly prepared meal next time.  Salad wasn't mind blowing but it was good enough to have another return visitor.
Wonderful healthy food and menu! I like the space they're in too.  Very popular though so it  does get crowded.
First time here. Loved my baked egg hash. I also added bacon. Also tried the citrus brioche and love it. Will be back!

Walked here for breakfast which is located on the corner. It's a cute little place with tables and delicious coffee. They have a variety of food and beverage options. I go the everything toast with lox,cream cheese, and with other sprouts and veggies on top. It was delicious and it was exactly what I needed to start the day.Overall, a really cute place with great toast and coffee.
Great croissant and other options. I'd like to see more options for breakfast. The place does get busy and gets traffic

Yum. I seem to live off of baked goods and black coffee; both are found in ample, delicious supply at Jane.  Came early Sunday morning and was able to order and sit pretty quick.  Timed that well because 5 minutes later, the line was almost out the door.  Will be back to try more of their yum menu.
Adorable.  Great cold brew and the food looked amazing.  Seems like a trendy place but with good service.

I want to like this spot. And I actually really like the location on California Street! But I don't love Jane on Larkin, unfortunately. I've been here a few times and I think it's a solid 3/5. The food is decent and fresh, if a little over-priced. I don't really like their bread -- too tough for avocado toast in my opinion. The menu options just don't hit the spot for me, so I always spend a ton of time perusing it and end up feeling like I've compromised. It's difficult to find seating during the brunch rush, and when you do it's kind of uncomfortable. Eh. It's fine, I just don't love it.

So I fell in love with their toasts. We had Fig Jam and ricotta toast. It's a dessert toast. The bread was toasted just right! I am a sucker for figs, I wished there were actual figs as a topping not just a jam. But it's name is fig jam & ricotta so I cannot complain. If lived closer to Mazarine I would definitely up for trying all other toasts each weekend. Next up tomato ricotta and basil toast for me!The atmosphere is great as well, pretty spacious and good to work/read or have a chatty time with friends.

Stopped by for breakfast this morning- even with a line, the orders come up quickly. LOVED the overnight oats made with cocoa nibs, chia seeds, vanilla, honey, almond milk and topped with sliced strawberries and blueberries. I was worried about it being to sweet, but it was actually perfect. They also make a fab latte. Recommend.

Unlike what someone posted 40 minutes ago, we came here at 8:30 and there was no line and plenty of seating. There is also plenty of options for people who do not want eggs or maybe vegetarian. The coffee was amazing and I love that there is an almond milk or oat milk option. The toast was perfect. I had the eggs and avocado, my significant other had the smoked salmon, and we shared the ricotta and fig jam. I would recommend this place to anyone looking for a healthy lunch or breakfast with a great atmosphere.

Was very excited about this place. After waiting in line for 25 minutes I have been told they can't make my eggs hard boiled (even though I am pregnant and not suppose to have raw eggs), also that to get a coffee it would be another 20 minutes wait. In addition there were no tables for people who actually ordered food even though there were plenty of people at the tables with their laptops who weren't eating. Maybe a good place for quick bite but don't expect to have a good sit down experience.

Came here for breakfast and ordered the beet hummus toast, which came with avocado on top. It was visually stunning, with the vibrance of the beet. There was a very generous serving of hummus on top. There were also cubes of cheese, which added nice texture contrast agains the smoothness of the hummus and the crunch of the toast. I did think the toast was a bit too toasted, as it was difficult to cut into. The crumbs would go flying around the table. However, it was a good level of toasted from a taste perspective.
$17 for 2 lattes because they were half decaf? Overpriced and unfriendly. Food was awful.

When travelling I don't generally go to the same place twice, but Mazarine was an exception. I found Mazarine when searching for Australian Coffee and the reviews looked pretty good. Now I know why. Not only was the coffee great, but the breakfast options were amazing. Definitely a must if your an Australian coffee snob like I was :-). Friendly for kids as well, and the service was friendly. Just be mindful that not a lot of places like taking $50 & $100 bills (if your travelling) due to counterfeit so bring some smaller denominations.

Legit CoffeeBest Iced Latte - they really get the balance right. You can from the photo they are very precise with the measurements. They also have have various types of open face toast sandwiches. I ordered the bacon, egg and avocado (see photo). I asked them to smash the avocados, it's normally served in slices.Highly recommend and will be visiting tomorrow again.
Great food. Seriously. Great food!!! Our coffees were really good too!!!  Super friendly staff. Wonderful eating on the patio.I'd definitely eat there again.

While perusing Yelp for a breakfast spot on our trip, we looked through  lot of businesses, but thought the pictures of food from Mazarine Coffee looked amazingly delectable. Those photos did not lie!Mazarine has a wealth of choices that are healthy, hearty, and sweet. There was so much to choose from, I wanted to have at least three meals worth. Alas, it was my last day in town, so I went with the Marshmallows & Chocolate sweet toast. Do not regret that decision one iota. The bread was fresh, toppings very flavorful. There was also enough there to actually satiate my appetite...which was kind of a bummer, because I really was searching for any excuse to eat more.It's in the title, but I'm saving it for last. I generally stick with black coffee, which is make or break for the coffee shop. You have to be able to have just a good cup o' joe. Well, Mazarine made it. It was not too acidic, good & rich. My associate got a cold brew latte, and absolutely loved it.

The service was great, all friendly and attentive staff. My matcha latte was just ok, it was a little bitter for me and not as creamy as I like. I ordered the strawberry jam and ricotta toast with bacon added on and that was insanely delicious. Don't go in there with the hopes of eating it there, the place is very small with very limited open, shared table seating, and we ended up waiting awhile to get somewhere to sit. This is a great place to just grab something and take it with. All in all I would return but I would order a different drink and I'd take it to go.

I'm glad that my coworker told me about this spot. It is never worth it to buy fancy toast because it is cheaper to make it yourself. However, I love buying fancy toast to treat myself. For a fancy toast spot, this place is not too expensive. It is average price and has a lot of variety.The thing I like the most about this coffee shop is that it is good luck. I was going to the test center to take a test and ate here before that. Luckily I passed! Perhaps it is because the toast gave me enough energy to think and was not too filling that I would fall asleep.So would I recommend? Yes. And I may come back before my next test too.
This was really average. Nothing phenomenal about the setting or the food. I was there with my family and all had toasts. They were good but not worth the $10 each in my opinion.

The avocado toast:I had the Bacon, Egg & Avocado Toast, It was definitely the most filling of all the avocado toasts, so as far as quantity goes, it's probably the most worth. However, the pesto was pretty overwhelming - I probably would not order this again. Also, the pain de mie, while good quality bread, did not seem like the best choice for avocado toast. It was a weird combo and made the dish difficult to eat.The coffee:I got a peppermint mocha, which was $7 (I was in a splurging mood). The regular mochas are $6. Still a bit excessive, even for San Francisco. Pretty latte art, but nothing terribly memorable.The environment:What really kills the rating is the lack of wifi. Otherwise, it would be one of the best places to do work in the area. The tables are wooden and large. There are outlets near the windows. There are also lots of yuppies having coffee chats, which is fun to listen to during free time. But no wifi :'(

My friend and I came here to try the avocado toast. I got the regular and she got the one with beets. The toast was pretty good. The bread was the right thickness and crunchy on the outside and chewy inside. It was also buttered and seasoned well. The avocado slices were fresh and I thought the slices of radish beyond being visually interesting added nice texture to the dish. I felt that the avocado could have used some salt though because it was a little bland.

Stopped by this place for a quick bite. They have wide selection of sweet and savory toasts. I tried their tomato ricotta and basil toast and my nephew tried avocado and egg toast. Both the dishes were yum. The seating was a bit tight. Luckily the cafe wasn't busy, and we found a table easily.

Based on the display, I think they use Ritual beans for their espresso drinks.  Really good. I'm dairy-free and don't always like the brand of alternative milks used in coffee shops, but their soy drinks did not disappoint!  Was here for a conference and got a soy cappuccino everyday :) They have amazing desserts from Third Culture Bakery as well.  Really enjoyed the ube custard cake.  Not sure where this was from, but the double ginger cookie they have is quite good too.  Perfectly spicy, with just the right touch of sweetness.  Lastly, their toast selection is incredible.  I tried the bacon, egg and avocado toast (swapped out the pan de mie for whole wheat bread) and really enjoyed it.  Only thing is there's no WiFi here and it's a bit dark so not really the ideal place to work, but nice European-cafe kind of vibes.

This place is a tourist trap.I was in town for a conference and this was an 8 minute walk from my location.Upon walking in, I was greeted by such a strong odor of cleaning supplies, I almost walked out. But, I was so sleepy and needed some caffeine for the conference, I decided to try this place out.I should have walked straight out!The avocado roasts are normal city prices yes. . . But there is barely any avocado on the toast!
